name: Fire Drill NO
description:
The Colorado Division of Fire Prevention & Control and The Colorado School Safety Resource Center schools to conduct a fire drill in the first ten days of school, and then each month following. These drills ensure that all students and staff are aware of emergency procedures and prepared for evacuation if needed.

Charter Contract Section, Schools Rights and Responsibilities, Reports The State’s adopted Fire Code requires schools to conduct a fire drill within ten days of the first day of school and once a month thereafter. The Code does not allow for the substitution of any other type of drill (e .g. lockdown, lockout, or shelter) for a fire drill. https://cdpsdocs.state.co.us/safeschools/Resources/Emergency_Drill_White_Paper_for_Public_Schools.pdf Review the above link for the complete code to better understand the requirements for the emergency plans, drills and recordkeeping.

step1.title: Plan Drill
step1.description:
Schedule your drill for an appropriate time in the first two weeks of the month. 

Drills should be scheduled at unexpected times and under varying conditions each month (i.e. during different class periods, during lunch, or between class periods). 

Ensure that all students and staff have been prepared to execute evacuation procedures. Consider starting with planned or announced drills early in the year, progressing to unannouced drills as the year goes on.

step2.title: Execute Drill
step2.description:
Conduct your drill and record the duration. 

If your building has an alarm system, this must be used in the drill. Contact your alarm provider to put your system into "test mode" prior to starting the drill to avoid contacting the authorities. 

Inadvertent or false alarms cannot be used in place of a drill.

step3.title: Submit Drill Information
step3.description:
[b][color=rgb(0, 0, 0)][highlight=transparent]Submission:[/highlight][/color][/b]
[color=rgb(0, 0, 0)][highlight=transparent](1) A report of 2024/2025 school year fire drills (each month's report)[/highlight][/color]
[color=rgb(0, 0, 0)][highlight=transparent](2) Updated emergency plans[/highlight][/color]
[color=rgb(0, 0, 0)][highlight=transparent](3) Emergency contact information[/highlight][/color]

name: Weekly Enrollment
description: Per the school's Charter Contract with the District, enrollment data must be shared weekly from the start of the fiscal year through the October count day. This information allows the District to remain aware and responsive to school needs and budgets as they relate to total enrollment numbers.

step1.title: Collect Enrollment Data
step1.description: Utilizing the school's internal student information system (SIS), collect enrollment numbers (total and by grade).

step2.title: Complete Enrollment Form
step2.description:
Use the data collected in Step 1 to complete the attached template. 

This template should be downloaded to your computer and updated each week to save time and ensure all week-to-week enrollment numbers are saved in the same document.

step3.title: Review & Submit
step3.description: Verify all information in the attached document is correct and submit.

name: Staff Evaluation - Snapshot
description: The staff interchange is a set of three files which contain all staff data for a school year. The staff profile contains the staff demographics and educational background, the staff assignment contains the current assignment data for all staff and the staff evaluation contains the current year evaluation data for all licensed personnel. These interchange files are intended to be transactional in nature therefore allowing LEAs to submit data regularly to CDE and clean the data as they go.

step1.title: Collect & Review Data
step1.description:
Locate your previously submitted Staff Evaluation file and any error reports.

Important Notes: 
[ml][ol][li indent=0 align=left]CDE does not need evaluation data for schools with waivers. [/li][li indent=0 align=left]If schools use the RANDA system for capturing evaluations, please only fill out the profile template and we will be able to draw the evaluation from there directly and won't need them to send that data. [/li][li indent=0 align=left]This is to report new staff as of December 1, 2023-June 30, 2024 ONLY.[/li][/ol][/ml]Update your staff profile interchange file if you had any new staff in the following job codes start after December 1St
[ml][ul][ul data=1][li indent=1 align=left]Teachers: 201, 202, 206, 216, 222, 226[/li][li indent=1 align=left]SP: 211, 231, 233, 234, 235, 236, 237, 238, 242[/li][li indent=1 align=left]Principal 105, 106[/li][/ul][/ul][/ml]
Resources:

[url=https://www.cde.state.co.us/datapipeline/datapipelinesnapshots-staffevaluation]https://www.cde.state.co.us/datapipeline/datapipelinesnapshots-staffevaluation[/url]

[url=https://www.cde.state.co.us/datapipeline/2023-2024staffevaluationsnapshotfilelayout]https://www.cde.state.co.us/datapipeline/2023-2024staffevaluationsnapshotfilelayout[/url]

[url=https://www.cde.state.co.us/datapipeline/snap_hr]https://www.cde.state.co.us/datapipeline/snap_hr[/url]

step2.title: Update Files
step2.description: Update these files to reflect any necessary changes or error remediation.

step3.title: Submit Files
step3.description:
Submit your Staff Evaluation file through Reportwell for review. This should be your final, error-free file for final submission to CDE.

PLEASE NOTE: If your file has errors, you MUST fix the errors and resubmit quickly (preferably within a few hours) so that the team at D49 can make the necessary adjustments and resubmit to CDE to get an error free report. The final, error free report is due to CDE on Aug. 7th.

name: Quarterly Financial Statement (Q4)
description: In accordance with Colorado code and charter contracts, D49 schools are required to prepare (C.R.S. §22-45-102(1)(b)) and post (C.R.S. §22-44-301) quarterly financial reports to ensure fiscal responsibility, oversight, and transparency. These reports must be submitted in a timely manner: within 45 days of the end of each quarter.

step1.title: Collect Financial Data
step1.description:
Collect financial data from internal accounting systems for the previous quarter (Apr-Jun). 

Ensure included are budget vs. actuals (current and YTD), as well as information which demostrates financial health and projected revenue/expenses (accounting for October counts).

step2.title: Enter Financial Data
step2.description:
Review the financial data and prepare for submission. This data should include at minimum: 
- Account codes following the CDE Chart of Accounts
- Current budget
- Month-to-date actuals
- Year-to-date actuals

All data should be collected and recorded in the attached template (Excel required for submission).

step3.title: Submit Data
step3.description: Review the data for accuracy and download as an Excel file (.xls) - the platform will not accept other file types for this submission.

name: Financial Transparency- Quarterly Website Check
description:
In alignment with the Financial Transparency Act (C.R.S. 22-44-301 et seq.) and the Charter Contract, all charter schools are required to post financial data and information in an free, accessible, and downloadable format. Schools must post and update financial documents regularly, to maintain financial transparency. For more information, you can visit the District or state websites: 
- Colorado K-12 Financial Transparency
- D49 Financial Transparency

step1.title: Collect & Review Financial Documents
step1.description:
If you are a new school, review and collect the list of required financial documentation. If you are an existing school, ensure all information and documentation is present and accessible on your website. 
- Charter School Adopted Budget - Including Uniform Budget Summary (current and prior two years) 
- Charter School Financial Audit (current and prior two years)
- Charter School Salary Schedules or Policies (current and prior two years) 
- List of Waivers Received by the Charter School
- Standardized Description and Rationale for Each Automatic Waiver
- Federal Form 990, 990-EZ, or 990-PF and any associated schedules (if you filed an extension for your 990(s), please enter a note into the benchmark and publish the extension on the website)
- Other Charter School-Specific Financial Information
- Link to Authorizing School District’s Financial Transparency Webpage
- Link to Public Financial Transparency Website View

step2.title: Review & Updated Website
step2.description:
Review and update all documentation as needed. Test all document links and downloads to ensure functionality.

Please note, all documents must be posted or updated within 60 days after completion or receipt of the applicable report, statement, or document.

Additionally, the Financial Transparency icon with the Colorado Flag must be found on the home page of school's website and link to all information included in this report (icon image available in Resources).

step3.title: Ready for Review
step3.description:
Once all information has been updated and added to the website, complete the report by checking "There is nothing to upload for this report" on the Completion page. 

Optional: Upload a screenshot of the website showing the visible links/files for all financial documents (please do not upload all documents here).

name: Secretary of State Filing
description: In order to remain in operation, all charter schools must be incorporated as a Colorado non-profit corporations. Once established, schools must continue to operate as Colorado non-profit corporations and assure that its operation is in accordance with its articles of incorporation and bylaws and by remaining in “Good Standing” status, meaning that statutory filing requirements have been met with the state office.

step1.title: Maintain & Verify Standing
step1.description: As an existing school, stay in “Good Standing” status by ensuring all statutory filing requirements have been met with the Secretary of State's office. Information on noncompliance and deliquency issues can be found here.

step2.title: Retrieve Certificate
step2.description:
Navigate to the Secretary of State's Business website and select "Certificate of Good Standing" from their list of services. 

Enter your school name in Business Database Search and click Search. Select your school by clicking on the ID Number.

On your school's page, scroll down to the "Get a Certificate of Good Standing" link. Review the certificate and verify school standing

step3.title: Download Certificate
step3.description:
Once verified, download a copy of the certificate. 

Save a copy for your records and submit another here.

name: July - Board Meeting Agenda
description: In the interest of transparency and in alignment with the Colorado Open Meetings Act, charter boards are required to provide an agenda in advance of all monthly board meetings. This agenda provides context for both board members and the public on the content to be discussed in the board meeting.

step1.title: Determine Content
step1.description: Through consultation with board committees and the Board Chair, determine appropriate content for the upcoming board meeting.

step2.title: Create Agenda
step2.description:
Organize content for the board meeting into an agenda. 

Topics may include (but are not limited to): Call to Order, Approval of Previous Minutes, Financial Reports, Academic Reports, New Business, Public Comments, Executive Session (if necessary), Adjournment (a template is provided as a reference).

step3.title: Submit Agenda
step3.description:
Review the agenda with necessary board members. Once finalized, submit the agenda through Reportwell. 

Though the due date is the end of the month, this MUST be submitted at latest one week before your monthly meeting. Please indicate the planned meeting date in the comments with your submission.

name: June - Board Meeting Minutes
description: In the interest of transparency and in alignment with the Colorado Open Meetings Act, charter boards are required to keep minutes at all monthly board meetings. These minutes then must be reviewed for accuracy and approved by board members at subsequent meetings and provided as public record.

step1.title: Record Meeting Minutes
step1.description:
At your monthly board meeting, ensure an individual is identified to take the meeting minutes. These minutes should align to the previously provided agenda for that month's meeting. 

Minutes do not need to be a full transcript of the meeting, however they should include relevant content, questions, and comments. Any votes taken should also be recorded in the minutes (see sample minutes for example). 

After the meeting, this person should review and edit their notes for clarity and accuracy and send them to the Board Chair and Principal.

step2.title: Approve Minutes
step2.description:
Previous meeting minutes should be included with materials for the next board meeting. Before and during the meeting, board member must review and vote to approve the meeting minutes.

In general, the approval of meeting minutes takes place in the following month (i.e. June minutes are approved and submitted in July).

step3.title: Submit Minutes
step3.description:
Once approved, meeting minutes should be downloaded and uploaded to Reportwell. 

If previous meeting minutes have not been approved by the item due date, add a note to Reportwell indicating the date of the upcoming board meeting and when approved minutes will be uploaded.

name: Functional Capacity
description: The functional capacity report for a school in Colorado assesses the school's ability to accommodate the current student population efficiently and effectively.

step1.title: Room Count
step1.description: How many rooms are in your building?

step2.title: Count Students
step2.description: [color=rgb(0, 0, 0)]How many seats are available for the facility (for student use)?[/color]

step3.title: Report Number of Seats
step3.description: Use the notes section or upload a PDF/Excel spreadsheet to report the number of rooms in your building and the total number of seats your building provides for student use.

name: EOY - Summer Graduates
description: The purpose of the Student End of Year (EOY) snapshot is to collect enrollment and outcome information for students during the school year. This includes demographic information and student’s entry and exit from public schools within a district. The data from this collection is used to derive the graduation, dropout, mobility, and stability rates.

step1.title: Review Graduation Requirements
step1.description:
Review your student data for any students who have not yet met graduation thresholds. 

This is the last day for any student to meet graduation requirements through summer school and other remediation, in order to be considered an on-time graduate.

step2.title: Update Data
step2.description:
Update students coursework and completion in alignment with graduation guidelines. 

Ensure all students are coded appropriately in your student information system with their associated graduation status.

step3.title: Verify Completion
step3.description: Check "There is nothing to complete for this report" and submit to Reportwell as verification that student data has been updated.

name: October Count - Weekly Data Integrity Check
description: The purpose of the Student October Snapshot is to determine funding for Local Education Agencies (LEAs) districts and schools by taking a count of students in attendance on the Pupil Enrollment Date (10/01/2024). Correct student count numbers are essential to ensuring the financial stability of your school. Frequent error checks are corrections are essential to accurate counts and funding.

step1.title: Review Data
step1.description: Review your current submission and any errors reported in the October Count Error Google Sheet with error details shared via ReportWell Messenger.

step2.title: Correct Errors
step2.description:
Correct any reported errors from the current submission. 

Use the error notes on how to resolve them within PowerSchool and sign up for office hours if additional support is needed. CDE October Snapshot guidance is also included in Resources.

step3.title: Submit Data
step3.description:
Once all errors have been corrected, download your updated data (DEM and SSA files) and upload through Reportwell. 

When downloading your data files, please use the following naming convention: Schoolcode_ReportName_Errors_Date

name: Assurance of Compliance
description: The Assurance of Compliance document is an acknowledgement and agreenment by the school to abide by all reporting and administrative requirements laid out in the Charter Contract. By signing this document, the school indicates it is aware of the statutes, rules and policies set forth in the assurances, as well as certain information from governing documents, including the applicable charter school application (new school, renewal, or transfer) and contract. The school further acknowledges and confirms that it is in compliance with such statutes, rules, policies, and other applicable documents.

step1.title: Review Documents
step1.description:
Read through each item on Assurance of Compliance document as well as related compliance requirements in the Charter Application or Contract. 

These documents should be review by relevant school leaders and board members.

step2.title: Sign Assurances
step2.description: Once reviewed, update the signature pages with school and signer information. Signatures are required from School Leader and School Board President.

step3.title: Review & Submit
step3.description: Review & Submit

name: End of Fiscal Year Adjusted Trial Balance
description: [color=rgb(0, 0, 0)][highlight=rgb(255, 255, 255)]The description can be: A charter school’s end-of-year adjusted trial balance is a crucial financial report summarizing all ledger accounts to ensure that debits and credits match, providing a clear view of the school's economic status. It is essential for preparing financial statements and ensuring compliance with regulatory requirements. Submitting this adjusted trial balance involves gathering accurate financial data, compiling it correctly, adjusting entries following the audit, and submitting them to the appropriate authorities.[/highlight][/color]

step1.title: Review Financial Records
step1.description:
Ensure that all transactions for the year are recorded accurately. This includes verifying receipts, expenditures, payroll, and other financial activities.

Make necessary adjusting entries for accrued expenses, depreciation, and any other end-of-year adjustments to ensure the financial records reflect the true financial position.

step2.title: Generate Balance
step2.description: Compile the adjusted trial balance from the general ledger. Ensure that the total debits equal the total credits, indicating that the books are balanced. The adjusted trial balance must match the audit.

step3.title: Verify Balance
step3.description: Conduct an internal review of the adjusted trial balance to ensure accuracy and completeness before submitting on Reportwell.

Though the due date is the end of the month, this MUST be submitted no less than 24 hours before your monthly meeting. Please indicate the planned meeting date in the comments with your submission.

name: July - Board Meeting Minutes
description: In the interest of transparency and in alignment with the Colorado Open Meetings Act, charter boards are required to keep minutes at all monthly board meetings. These minutes then must be reviewed for accuracy and approved by board members at subsequent meetings and provided as public record.

step1.title: Record Meeting Minutes
step1.description:
At your monthly board meeting, ensure an individual is identified to take the meeting minutes. These minutes should align to the previously provided agenda for that month's meeting. 

Minutes do not need to be a full transcript of the meeting, however they should include relevant content, questions, and comments. Any votes taken should also be recorded in the minutes (see sample minutes for example). 

After the meeting, this person should review and edit their notes for clarity and accuracy and send them to the Board Chair and Principal.

step2.title: Approve Minutes
step2.description:
Previous meeting minutes should be included with materials for the next board meeting. Before and during the meeting, board member must review and vote to approve the meeting minutes.

In general, the approval of meeting minutes takes place in the following month (i.e. June minutes are approved and submitted in July).

step3.title: Submit Minutes
step3.description:
Once approved, meeting minutes should be downloaded and uploaded to Reportwell. 

If previous meeting minutes have not been approved by the item due date, add a note to Reportwell indicating the date of the upcoming board meeting and when approved minutes will be uploaded.

name: Policy for HB 24-1039: Non-Legal Name Change
description: The act requires school personnel to address a student by the student's chosen name and to use the student's chosen name in school and during extracurricular activities. The act deems it discriminatory to knowingly or intentionally use a name other than the student's chosen name or knowingly or intentionally avoiding or refusing to use a student's chosen name, unless done at the request of the student. The act allows a student who is subject to discrimination as a result of a failure or refusal to address the student by the student's chosen name to file a report with the school or a federal civil rights complaint. The act requires a school to implement a written policy outlining how the school will honor a student's request to use a chosen name.

step1.title: Read and Understand Policy
step1.description:
[color=rgb(0, 0, 0)][url=https://leg.colorado.gov/sites/default/files/documents/2024A/bills/2024a_1039_01.pdf]https://leg.colorado.gov/sites/default/files/documents/2024A/bills/2024a_1039_01.pdf[/url][/color]

[color=rgb(0, 0, 0)]CDE will create a task force by June 30, 2024 that will examine existing policies on how to best implement student non-legal name change policies. [/color]
Requires the task force to submit a report to the department detailing the recommended policy guidelines by January 1, 2025. 
Requires the department to publish the report on its website and submit the report to the superintendent of each school district and chief administrator of each institute charter school by February 1, 2025.

step2.title: Write Draft
step2.description:
A LOCAL EDUCATION PROVIDER SHALL IMPLEMENT A WRITTEN POLICY OUTLINING HOW THE LOCAL EDUCATION PROVIDER WILL HONOR A STUDENT'S REQUEST TO USE A CHOSEN NAME AND MAY INCLUDE A PROCESS PAGE 2-HOUSE BILL 24-1039 FOR INCLUDING A STUDENT'S CHOSEN NAME ON SCHOOL RECORDS. A WRITTEN POLICY ADOPTED PURSUANT TO THIS SUBSECTION (5) MUST COMPLY WITH THE FEDERAL "FAMILY EDUCATIONAL RIGHTS AND PRIVACY ACT OF 1974", 20 U.S.C. SEC. 1232g, AS AMENDED, AND SECTION 22-1-123. 

Meet with appropriate admin and board members to write policy for [highlight=transparent]Concerning Non-Legal Name Changes for Students in Schools. [/highlight]

step3.title: Write Final Draft and Submit
step3.description: Submit approved policy in PDF or DOC format.

name: Policy for SB 23-296
description: The act requires a public school that enrolls students in any of grades kindergarten through 12 (public school) to accept formal reports of harassment or discrimination in writing or in person; by phone, e-mail, or online form. A report received by a public school that alleges harassment or discrimination is confidential.

step1.title: Read and Understand Senate Bill
step1.description:
[url=https://leg.colorado.gov/bills/sb23-296]https://leg.colorado.gov/bills/sb23-296[/url]

[url=https://leg.colorado.gov/sites/default/files/2023a_296_signed.pdf]https://leg.colorado.gov/sites/default/files/2023a_296_signed.pdf[/url]

[highlight=transparent]On or before [/highlight][b][highlight=transparent]July 1, 2024[/highlight][/b][highlight=transparent], each local education provider shall adopt a written policy that protects students experiencing harassment or discrimination. The policy adopted pursuant to this subsection (3) is [/highlight][b][highlight=transparent]SEPARATE FROM AND IN ADDITION[/highlight][/b][highlight=transparent] to any policy a public school or local education provider must adopt pursuant to Title IX. Each local education provider shall periodically review and update the policy.[/highlight]

[highlight=transparent]The policy must be written in plain language and include the following:[/highlight]
[ml][ul][li indent=0 align=left][highlight=transparent]An explanation of the school’s role in responding to reports of harassment or discrimination, preventing recurrence of harassment or discrimination, and remedying effects of the harassment or discrimination.[/highlight][/li][/ul][/ml]

step2.title: Write Draft
step2.description:
Each school district, charter school, or board of cooperative services (local education provider) shall adopt procedures for investigating reports of harassment or discrimination. A local education provider shall retain the records of a harassment or discrimination report for 7 years.

Each local education provider shall adopt a written policy (policy) that protects students experiencing harassment or discrimination. The policy must include the following:
[ml][ul][li indent=0 align=left]Information on reporting options for students, including contact information for the person designated to receive reports;[/li][li indent=0 align=left]An explanation of the school's role in responding to reports of harassment or discrimination;[/li][li indent=0 align=left]Information about resources for victims of violence;[/li][li indent=0 align=left]A prohibition on a school using a student report of harassment or discrimination or information learned during an investigation as the basis for, or a consideration in, investigating or exacting any disciplinary response for specified school violations by the student related to the harassment or discrimination; and[/li][li indent=0 align=left]Information about available accommodations and supportive measures.[/li][/ul][/ml]
Meet with appropriate admin and board members to write policy for [highlight=transparent]Concerning Protections for Students Against Discriminatory Practices at School. [/highlight]

step3.title: Write Final and Submit
step3.description: Submit approved policy in PDF or DOC format.

description:
[highlight=rgb(250, 204, 204)]**PLEASE READ THE STAFF INTERCHANGE LAYOUT RESOURCE TO ASSIST IN FILLING OUT THE TEMPLATES AND THERE ARE CHANGES CDE HAS MADE FOR THIS 2023-2024 COLLECTION**[/highlight]
Staff Interchange -Staff Evaluation staff interchange is a set of three files which contain all staff data for a school year. The staff profile contains the staff demographics and educational background, the staff assignment contains the current assignment data for all staff and the staff evaluation contains the current year evaluation data for all licensed personnel. These interchange files are intended to be transactional in nature therefore allowing LEAs to submit data regularly to CDE and clean the data as they go.

Resources:

name: Financial Transparency- Quarterly Website Check
description:
In alignment with the Financial Transparency Act (C.R.S. 22-44-301 et seq.) and the Charter Contract, all charter schools are required to post financial data and information in an free, accessible, and downloadable format. Schools must post and update financial documents regularly, to maintain financial transparency. For more information, you can visit the District or state websites: - Colorado K-12 Financial Transparency - D49 Financial Transparency.

Pursuant to C.R.S. 22-44-305 “Commencing July 1, 2017, and on a continuing basis thereafter, each school district and charter school shall post, in a location and format that can be easily accessed and downloaded, for free public access on its website maintained pursuant to this part 3 a list of the statutes for which the school district or charter school has received a waiver from the state board of education and, for each waiver that is not an automatic waiver, a copy of the plan that explains the manner in which the school district or charter school will meet the intent of the waived statute.” Furthermore, “Each school district and charter school shall update the information provided pursuant to subsection (1) of this section within thirty days after a waiver is revoked or a new waiver is granted.”

step1.title: Collect & Review Financial Documents
step1.description:
If you are a new school, review and collect the list of required financial documentation. If you are an existing school, ensure all information and documentation is present and accessible on your website. 
- Charter School Adopted Budget - Including Uniform Budget Summary (current and prior two years) 
- Charter School Financial Audit (current and prior two years)
- Charter School Salary Schedules or Policies (current and prior two years) 
- List of Waivers Received by the Charter School
- Standardized Description and Rationale for Each Automatic and Non-automatic Waiver
- Federal Form 990, 990-EZ, or 990-PF and any associated schedules (if you filed an extension for your 990(s), please enter a note into the benchmark and publish the extension on the website)
- Other Charter School-Specific Financial Information
- Link to Authorizing School District’s Financial Transparency Webpage
- Link to Public Financial Transparency Website View

step2.title: Review & Updated Website
step2.description:
Review and update all documentation as needed. Test all document links and downloads to ensure functionality.

Please note, all documents must be posted or updated within 60 days after completion or receipt of the applicable report, statement, or document.

Additionally, the Financial Transparency icon with the Colorado Flag must be found on the home page of school's website and link to all information included in this report (icon image available in Resources).

step3.title: Ready for Review
step3.description:
Once all information has been updated and added to the website, complete the report by checking "There is nothing to upload for this report" on the Completion page. 

Optional: Upload a screenshot of the website showing the visible links/files for all financial documents (please do not upload all documents here).

name: Asbestos Management Plan NO
description: Due to the frequent use of asbestos in building materials, all schools are required to inspect for and keep record of asbestos containing materials within the facility. If asbestos is present, schools must also develop an asbestos management plan complying with the provisions of the Colorado Air Quality Control Commission (5 CCR 1001-10, Regulation No. 8) and Environmental Protection Agency guidelines. This plan ensures the ongoing health and safety of students and faculty present in the facility daily.

step1.title: Identify & Record
step1.description:
After any new construction, renovation, or demolition, all materials must be sampled for asbestos (this includes, floor tile, mastic, ceiling tiles, joint compound, cove base, insulation, carpet glue). 

Your contractor should be able to provide you a letter which indicates that, "to the best of their knowledge no asbestos-containing material was used" to keep on file; and/or they can acquire letters from their subcontractors indicating the same. If these are not available you may be required to “cut out pieces of each items for testing.

Record the location of any asbestos-containing materials. Standard, "in-place" management of asbestos-containing material dictates that removal of these materials is not usually necessary unless the material is severely damaged or will be disturbed by a building demolition or renovation project. However, these locations must be recorded and included in your asbestos management plan.

step2.title: Create Management Plan
step2.description:
Create an Asbestos Management Plan in alignment with the results of inspection. This plan should include at minimum:

-Name/address of each building and the incidence and type of asbestos-containing material. 
-Date of the original school inspection
-Plan for re-inspections
-Blueprint that clearly identifies the location of asbestos-containing materials
-Description of response or preventive measures taken to reduce asbestos exposure
-Description of steps taken to inform workers, teachers, and students or their legal guardians about inspections, re-inspections, response actions, and periodic surveillance

step3.title: Submit Plan
step3.description:
Ensure your maintenance and inspection schedules and activities align to any requirements laid out in your Asbestos Management Plan. Edit your plan as needed in the event subsequent monitoring and inspection suggest a safety concern. 

Submit your inspection report(s), letter(s) of assurance from contractors and/or your Asbestos Management Plan here.

name: Draft of Assurances for Financial Accreditation
description: In accordance with state law (C.R.S. 22-30.5-112(7)), all charter schools are required to comply with all of the state financial and budget rules, regulations, and financial reporting requirements, in,  with which the chartering school district is required to comply.  The assurance form is completed by schools to attest to their compliance with these regulations.

step1.title: Review Assurances & Financial Practices
step1.description:
Review the assurance form (attached in Resources) and compare to current school financial practices, verifying alignment. 

If the school is out of compliance with any assurance statement, implement changes to financial practices or obtain documentation for deviations.

step2.title: Complete Assurance Form
step2.description:
Download and complete the assurance form with your school information. 

If you answer "No" to any indicators, you MUST complete the Form A attachment.

step3.title: Finalize & Submit
step3.description:
Once you have downloaded the forms, please clicked no submission and submit. 

D49 Finance requires a final AFA (Due in October) to ensure completion and compliance upon the official deadline in order to submit.

Your charter schools specialist will send all Final Assurances for Final Accreditation forms to CDE via schoolfinance@cde.state.co.us

name: Weekly Enrollment
description: Per the school's Charter Contract with the District, enrollment data must be shared weekly from the start of the fiscal year through the October count day. This information allows the District to remain aware and responsive to school needs and budgets as they relate to total enrollment numbers.

step1.title: Collect Enrollment Data
step1.description: Utilizing the school's internal student information system (SIS), collect enrollment numbers (total and by grade).

step2.title: Complete Enrollment Form
step2.description:
Use the data collected in Step 1 to complete the attached template. 

This template should be downloaded to your computer and updated each week to save time and ensure all week-to-week enrollment numbers are saved in the same document.

step3.title: Review & Submit
step3.description: Verify all information in the attached document is correct and submit.

name: October Count - Clear Moving Class
description: The purpose of the Student October Snapshot is to determine funding for Local Education Agencies (LEAs) districts and schools by taking a count of students in attendance on the Pupil Enrollment Date (10/01/2024). Per state board rule 1-CCR-301-1, LEAs are required to maintain adequate documentation of students transferring out of the school. This documentation assures all students are accounted for and prevents erroneous drop-outs.

step1.title: Update Records
step1.description:
Review state guidance for adequate procedures and documentation of transfers out of the school (see Resources).

Through the first months of school, update student enrollment records for new and transferred students.

step2.title: Process Transfers
step2.description:
For any students who have indicated a transfer to another school, request "Confirmation of Enrollment and Attendance" to new schools. 

LEAs are expected to respond promptly to one another regarding requests for transcripts or confirmation of enrollment and attendance. Per state board rule, LEAs must respond within two weeks of receiving the request with the exception of students in out-of-home placements whose records must be sent within five days of receiving the request. 

Any students confirmed to be transferring from the school should be placed in the "Moving Class" (full guidance and procedures in Resources).

step3.title: Clear Moving Class
step3.description:
Once transfers have been confirmed through documentation, clear out the moving class to ensure accurate numbers of enrollment. No student should be dropped from the moving class without proper attempts of locating the student. 

In addition, no student on an IEP or a 504 plan should be dropped from the moving class without communication with the Zone Special Education Coordinator (IEP) or Nancy Lemmond (504).

Some situations may prevent the ability to clear out a student from the Moving class, such as students within the truancy process. If you are unable to clear a student provide details of their truancy status to the D49 SIS Team(d49sis@d49.org). 

Verify your moving class has been cleared in Reportwell - select "There is nothing to submit for this report"

name: October Count - Bell Schedules
description: The purpose of the Student October Snapshot is to determine funding for Local Education Agencies (LEAs) districts and schools by taking a count of students in attendance on the Pupil Enrollment Date (10/01/2024). Daily schedules are used in the October count to verify part or full time status and funding codes.

step1.title: Create Schedules
step1.description:
Create schedules for all student and calendar variations.

This should include the regular bell schedule, as well as early-release or late start (i.e. weather delay) schedules, or schedules specific to certain students or student groups.

step2.title: Download Schedules
step2.description:
Once schedules have been finalized, save copies with the appropriate naming convention: Schoolcode_BellSchedule_Type. 

Example: 1275_Bell_Schedule_2HourDelay

step3.title: Submit
step3.description: Upload your schedule to Reportwell.

name: October Count - School Calendar
description: The purpose of the Student October Snapshot is to determine funding for Local Education Agencies (LEAs) districts and schools by taking a count of students in attendance on the Pupil Enrollment Date (10/01/2024). The year-long school calendar is an essential communication tool, and in the October count, ensures compliance with the minimum student contact day requirement for Colorado to establish funding.

step1.title: Create Calendar
step1.description:
Create or retrieve your school calendar. This can be the district calendar only if your school does not have any variation of days such as Red/Blue fridays, late start Thursdays, or a different start date

Verify any dates off - federal holidays, seasonal breaks, conference, PD - and the total number of contact days (minimum 160). 

For full calendar creation guidance see "Annual School Calendar w/ Contact Days"

step2.title: Download Schedules
step2.description: Once the calendar has been finalized, save with the appropriate naming convention: Schoolcode_SchoolCalendar

step3.title: Submit
step3.description: Upload your schedule to Reportwell.

name: October Count - IEP Summary Pages
description: The purpose of the Student October Snapshot is to determine funding for Local Education Agencies (LEAs) districts and schools by taking a count of students in attendance on the Pupil Enrollment Date (10/01/2024). In order to determine student funding status and enrollment, schools information on any students with varied schedule due to Individualized Learning Plans (IEPs).

step1.title: Identify Students
step1.description:
Identify any students that are on a reduced schedule only or participating in homebound education. 

Note these classifications should be supported and verified through documentation in the student's IEP.

step2.title: Update Records
step2.description:
Ensure accurate records by ensure their funding status is up to date in your Student Information System (SIS). 

Funding guidance and SIS instruction in Resources.

step3.title: Collect Documentation
step3.description:
Collect the summary from each student on reduced or homebound schedules. 

Save copies of these document using the naming convention: SchoolCode_IEPSummary_StudentSASID

Upload all student files to Reportwell.

name: October Count - Schedule Verification
description: The purpose of the Student October Snapshot is to determine funding for Local Education Agencies (LEAs) districts and schools by taking a count of students in attendance on the Pupil Enrollment Date (10/01/2024). In order to be accurately counted, all active students must have an assigned schedule for the entire school year.

step1.title: Review Data
step1.description: Verify all accuracy of all active students and schedules in your SIS.

step2.title: Verify Schedules
step2.description:
Confirm every active student has a full schedule for the entire school year. 

Verify all no-show and inactive students have the "moving class" on their schedule.

step3.title: Certify Completion
step3.description: Verify all records are updated through Reportwell - select "There is nothing to submit for this report" to submit.

name: October Count - Part-Time Funding
description: Double check your students schedule to verify if they qualify for part-time or full time funding (mainly secondary). If part-time, adjust their funding code as referenced in the linked document.

step1.title: Identify Students
step1.description: Identify any students that may qualify as part-time (this mainly applies to secondary students).

step2.title: Adjust Funding
step2.description: Adjust the funding codes for any students identified as part time in your SIS (see Resources for guidance and funding codes).

step3.title: Certify Completion
step3.description: Verify all records are updated through Reportwell - select "There is nothing to submit for this report" to submit.

name: October Count - Post Alternative Course Catalog to Website
description: The purpose of the Student October Snapshot is to determine funding for Local Education Agencies (LEAs) districts and schools by taking a count of students in attendance on the Pupil Enrollment Date (10/01/2024). In this process, high schools, online schools, and unique schools/programs are required to submit their student handbook and course descriptions to ensure appropriate funding. This is optional, but encouraged for all other schools.

step1.title: Upload to website
step1.description:
Ensure your alternative course catalog meets all CDE requirements. [color=rgb(17, 85, 204)][url=https://docs.google.com/document/d/1oPny3Kw3w9Myy0zAmWiUW_aoV8iiNII9vLNg7GOmDBo/edit?usp=sharing]We have linked that example here for your quick reference.[/url][/color] 

[ml][ol][li indent=0 align=left]Have a separate course catalog listing only the alternative education classes [/li][/ol][/ml][ml][ul][ul data=1][li indent=1 align=left]These classes include: [/li][ul data=2][li indent=2 align=left]Work Study (internships, etc)[/li][li indent=2 align=left]Blended Learning[/li][li indent=2 align=left]Independent Study[/li][li indent=2 align=left]Supplemental Online[/li][/ul][li indent=1 align=left]This also includes expelled students at all grade levels for any/all online classes they will be taking[/li][ul data=2][li indent=2 align=left]Since expulsions
