name: Annual Financial Audit
description: Each year, schools must complete an annual financial audit by a certified public accountant, chosen by the School's governing body. In accordance with state and CDE rules and regulations, this annual audit will review the school's accounting practices, financial management, and and administrative operations.

step1.title: Identify Audit Firm
step1.description:
In collaboration with the school's Board of Directors, identify an accounting firm to complete the annual audit. 

Reach out to the identified firm to verify availability for the upcoming audit and obtain a letter of engagement. 

It is recommended to start this process close to the end of the fiscal year to ensure adequate for the firm to collect documentation and conduct the audit ahead of the September 30th deadline.

step2.title: Conduct Audit
step2.description:
Gather all relevant financial documents, records, and reports that will be needed for the audit (this may include budgets, financial statements, receipts, invoices, payroll records, ect.)

Provide your audit with access to any requested or necessary documentation and information. The audit firm will conduct a thorough examination of your school's financial records and procedures to ensure compliance with relevant regulations and accounting standards.

Throughout the process, monitor progress and clarify any questions or concerns they may have about your school's finances or financial practices.

step3.title: Review & Finalize Audit
step3.description:
Once the audit is complete, review the findings and recommendations provided by the audit firm. Address any issues or concerns identified during the audit process.

After review, coordinate with your board to approve and finalize the audit. 

Submit your independent audit and finalized audited financial statements to the platform as a .pdf or .doc

name: Proof of Insurance
description:
In accordance with the terms of its charter, schools are required to maintain insurance coverage either purchased privately or through the School District. Maintenance of sufficient is necessary for schools to protect their property from damage, cover liabilities such as lawsuits, provide employee benefits, and ensure financial stability in the face of unforeseen events, offering peace of mind to stakeholders.


Minimum coverages required by the state have been included; these requirements will be reviewed and updated as needed, in the event that the compulsory insurance laws of the State of Colorado increase.

step1.title: Review Insurance Options
step1.description:
In collaboration with school leaders and board members, review and evaluate available insurance policies, coverage, and rates for renewal (existing schools) or establishment (new schools). 

Coverage can be obtained privately or through the district. Any private insurance company must be rated at least an A-VIII by A.M. Best Company.  

Selected coverage options can be found in the "Certificate of Liability Insurance" and "Evidence of Property Assurance" forms provided by your insurance agent.

step2.title: Establish or Renew Coverage
step2.description:
Establish coverage through your selected provider. Per the charter contract, minimum coverages and requirements are as follows:
- Comprehensive general liability coverage - $2,000,000 general aggregate, $1,000,000 each occurrence
- Officers, directors and employees errors and omissions - $2,000,000
- Educators Legal Liability - $2,000,000
- Excess/Umbrella Liability - $2,000,000
- Property insurance - as required by landlord covering owned or leased
- Crime Insurance - $250,000
- Motor Vehicle liability (if applicable) - $1,000,000
- Bonding (if applicable)
- Minimum amounts: $25,000
- Maximum amounts: $100,000
- Worker's compensation (as required by state law)

All coverages must include all employees and authorized volunteers of the school. Additionally, Errors and Omissions coverage must include all members of the Governing Board.

step3.title: Collect & Submit Documentation
step3.description:
Once finalized, collect and submit documentation for all required policies. 

For any insurance not purchased through the School District, the school must provide the School District risk management office with certificates of insurance for each type of coverage within a week of the time such coverages are bound.

If any coverage is canceled or changed in any way throughout the year, the school must also immediately notify both the Superintendent's office and risk management office of the change.

name: Annual Performance Report
description: Each year, school districts in Colorado are required to report school performance to the community, as required by the Every Student Succeeds Act. In accordance with contract section 3.2, D49 will complete this annual performance report (APR) for each school based on financial, academic, and governance metrics and ratings of the previous year.

step1.title: Review Requirements
step1.description: Review all necessary submissions for the annual performance report, in alignment with the charter contract and D49 guidance (see Resources).

step2.title: Compile Data
step2.description:
Collect all necessary data and resources required for the Annual Performance Report (APR). 

As a reminder, this should be all data from the PREVIOUS school year.

step3.title: Upload Documents
step3.description: Upload all required data and documents for completion of the APR.

name: September - Board Meeting Agenda
description: In alignment with Colorado's Open Meeting Law, board meeting agendas must be provided ahead of public board meetings. Public agendas not only provide transparancy, but also ensure meetings are organized and timely.

step1.title: Determine Content
step1.description: Through consultation with board committees and the Board Chair, determine appropriate content for the upcoming board meeting.

step2.title: Create Agenda
step2.description:
Organize content for the board meeting into an agenda. 

Topics may include (but are not limited to): Call to Order, Approval of Previous Minutes, Financial Reports, Academic Reports, New Business, Public Comments, Executive Session (if necessary), Adjournment (a template is provided as a reference).

step3.title: Submit Agenda
step3.description:
Review the agenda with necessary board members. 

Once finalized, submit the agenda to Reportwell.

name: August - Board Meeting Minutes
description: In the interest of transparency and in alignment with the Colorado Open Meetings Act, charter boards are required to keep minutes at all monthly board meetings. These minutes then must be reviewed for accuracy and approved by board members at subsequent meetings and provided as public record.

step1.title: Record Meeting Minutes
step1.description:
At your monthly board meeting, ensure an individual is identified to take the meeting minutes. These minutes should align to the previously provided agenda for that month's meeting. 

Minutes do not need to be a full transcript of the meeting, however they should include relevant content, questions, and comments. Any votes taken should also be recorded in the minutes (see sample minutes for example). 

After the meeting, this person should review and edit their notes for clarity and accuracy and send them to the Board Chair and Principal.

step2.title: Approve Minutes
step2.description:
Previous meeting minutes should be included with materials for the next board meeting. Before and during the meeting, board member must review and vote to approve the meeting minutes.

In general, the approval of meeting minutes takes place in the following month (i.e. June minutes are approved and submitted in July).

step3.title: Submit Minutes
step3.description:
Once approved, meeting minutes should be downloaded and uploaded to Reportwell. 

If previous meeting minutes have not been approved by the item due date, add a note to Reportwell indicating the date of the upcoming board meeting and when approved minutes will be uploaded.

name: Gym Floors (Mercury)
description: Ensuring a safe environment for students is paramount, and testing for mercury in gymnasium flooring is crucial for schools. Poured, rubberized gym flooring was once widely installed in school gymnasiums across the United States and can contain a mercury catalyst which emits vapors under certain conditions. Mercury exposure can have serious health implications, making regular inspections of such floors a necessity.

step1.title: Check Floors
step1.description:
Review any facility or construction documentation to determine if your gym floor may have the mercury-containing properties.

Please contact Tara Carey at tara.carey@d49.org or (719) [color=rgb(0, 0, 0)]719-491-3335 for questions. [/color]
[color=rgb(0, 0, 0)]﻿[/color]
[color=rgb(0, 0, 0)][highlight=transparent]If you do not have gym floors, [/highlight][/color][color=rgb(0, 0, 0)]choose no submission and submit.[/color]
[color=rgb(0, 0, 0)]﻿[/color]
[color=rgb(0, 0, 0)][highlight=transparent]﻿If you do not have rubberized flooring, choose no submission and submit.[/highlight][/color]

[color=rgb(0, 0, 0)][highlight=transparent]If you have rubberized flooring, submit inspection report.[/highlight][/color]

step2.title: Procure Inspection
step2.description:
Identify a third-party contractor capable of conducting inspection for mercury levels in your gymnasium.

In your inspection, they should check mercury levels in the air of any required spaces, in addition to a visual inspection for any areas of wear.

step3.title: Review Results
step3.description:
Review the results of the inspection, verifying that levels (if any) are within a safe range (see Resources). 

If needed, plan for remediation of any areas not meeting standards. 

Submit inspection results here.

name: Lead in Drinking Water NO
description: Lead in drinking water typically occurs because lead-containing pipes and plumbing materials corrode over time, creating a health hazard. To mitigate the risk of possible lead exposure to students and staff, schools are required to test their water for lead annually. Schools must collect and test drinking water in alignment with the Colorado Department of Public Health & Environment (CDPHE) guidelines.

step1.title: Contact Lab
step1.description:
Identify and contact a certified lab to conduct lead testing on your drinking water samples. The CDPHE maintains a list of certified labs which can be filtered specifically for those who test for lead. 

Consult with your select lab regarding collection procedures, including instructions on sample containers, preservation, labeling and shipping.

step2.title: Collect Samples
step2.description:
Conduct a walk-through of the facility and identify all fixtures used for drinking and cooking in the building while prioritizing high-risk locations. 

Develop a sampling sequence ensuring faucets are sampled in an order which avoids flushing fresh water through the plumbing system. Begin sampling closest to the building’s service line and work outward and upward.

Collect samples with 250 mL first draw samples at each location collected immediately after opening the faucet or valve. Each fixture must be sampled in the morning before any use to test water that has been stagnant for 8-18 hours. 

Review the guide in Resources for full details and instructions.

step3.title: Collect Results
step3.description:
Once samples have been collected, send them to your selected lab. After analysis is complete, the lab will provide results for each sample. 

Review these results in comparison to "safe" levels (<5 ppb). If levels warrant remediation, follow the steps outlined in the attached CDPHE guidance. Results must also be shared within two business days to the school/ child care employees and guardians.

Submit all results and evidence of remediation (if needed) here.

name: Charter Busing
description: To ensure the safety and efficiency of student transportation, charter schools in Colorado must submit necessary compliance documents to the Colorado Department of Education (CDE). Charter schools in Colorado are not required to provide transportation, but if they do, they are subject to all state and federal rules. Schools choosing to self-operate, or utilize a service provider, must ensure documentation that demonstrates adherence to state regulations, safety standards, and operational requirements. Full guidance on these requirements can be found of the CDE's transportation page.

step1.title: Create Transportation Plan
step1.description:
After reviewing all federal and DCE standards around transportation, create a plan through collaboration with school stakeholders. 

This plan should describe how transportation will be provided to students; including routing/distance guidelines, safety information, types of vehicles used, and whether to contract or self-operate. Additionally, this plan should include processes and procedures for ensuring compliance with state and federal guidelines as it relates to vehicle inspections, driver requirements, and more. 

[b]Statement from Susan Miller, Transportation Supervisor, CDE: [/b]
These rules are [u][highlight=yellow]not[/highlight][/u][u] [/u]intended to include:
2.02(a) Private motor vehicles used exclusively to carry members of the owner's household.
2.02(b) Transportation arrangements not authorized by the school district, charter school, or service provider, including but not limited to sharing of actual gasoline expense or participation in a carpool;
2.02(c) The operations of vehicles in bona fide emergency situations consistent with policies of the local board of education;
[highlight=yellow]2.02(d) Transportation conducted by an individual for activity trips (school related events), including parent volunteers, and coaches or teachers using a private motor vehicle; or[/highlight]
2.02(e) Transportation provided by a company or individual as part of their operation as a common carrier, or transportation network company operating pursuant to Section 40- 10.1-602, C.R.S., under the jurisdiction of the US Department of Transportation or the Public Utilities Commission.

Our Operation Rules 1 CCR 301-26 state the following – CDE regulations are NOT required under the following circumstances. However, I would like to suggest a couple of things. They are not required but a good best practice -
 
[ml][ol][li indent=0 align=left]Get a copy of the driver's license of the person driving.[/li][li indent=0 align=left]Make sure they have current car insurance in effect for the vehicle they will be using.[/li][li indent=0 align=left]Run a motor vehicle check on the driver to make sure they don’t have a horrific driving record.[/li][li indent=0 align=left]Have parent releases of liability for the students who would be riding in that vehicle who are not the student of the operator.[/li][/ol][/ml]
Be sure to consider the allocation of transportation to special student populations (Special Education, homeless youth) in this plan.

step2.title: Collect Compliance Documents
step2.description:
In alignment with the transportation plan, begin collecting necessary compliance documentation. If you choose to contract through a transportation service provider, this should be done for you. 

Review all federal and CDE guidelines for vehicle and driver requirements and complete/collect all required documentation (e.g. Clearinghouse/general background checks, drug test records, inspection reports). Ensure all documentation is stored and organized for review.

step3.title: Complete STAR Review
step3.description:
The CDE will perform periodic School Transportation Advisory Reviews (STAR) of charter schools and operators to ensure compliance with compliance items. A tentative schedule for these reviews can be found on the CDE's transportation page. 

After your review, respond with and take any necessary corrective actions, and save the review results for submission. 

Submit your review (or if using an transportation service provide, their certificate) here.

name: Fire Hydrant Inspection - Annual NO
description: Procuring an inspection for a school's fire hydrant is a crucial task to ensure the safety and compliance with fire safety regulations. Regular inspections help in identifying and rectifying any issues with the hydrant, ensuring it is functional in case of an emergency. You will need to contact the water district to verify if your hydrant(s) are owned by City/County or if you are responsible for the maintenance and inspections.

step1.title: Determine Hydrant Ownership
step1.description:
Survey your school campus and identify any nearby hydrants. 

Contact your local water district to verify if your hydrant(s) are owned by City/County or the school. 

If the school owns any of the hydrants, proceed to Step 2; if all nearby hydrants are owned by the City/County, proceed to Step 3.

step2.title: Schedule Inspection
step2.description:
Research and select a certified fire protection company or local fire department authorized to perform fire hydrant inspections. Request a quote and schedule the inspection.

Clear the area around the fire hydrant, remove obstructions, and gather all relevant documentation, including past inspection reports and maintenance records.

step3.title: Review Results
step3.description:
Review the results of your inspection and address deficiencies, if any. Provide any inspection records/reports here. 

If you do not own any fire hydrants, note this in the submission and submit without any attachments.

name: Fire Alarm Inspection - Internal NO
description: In accordance with Colorado state code and in alignment with best practices established by the National Fire Protection Agency (NFPA) standards, schools are required to inspect and test the function of their fire alarm systems regularly. In addition to inspections required annually by Certified Fire Inspectors (see "Fire Alarm Inspection - External"), schools must self-inspect and test systems on a weekly, monthly, and quarterly basis. These practices ensure the safety and well-being of all students and staff attending the school daily.

step1.title: Establish Policies
step1.description:
Review Colorado state codes and requirement, as well as the NFPA Standards and Codes for fire alarm safety (access available online) as needed to ensure alignment in the school's fire alarm systems. You may also choose to review previous inspection reports from past years. 

Using these resources, establish policies and procedures for the regular inspection and testing of your alarm system; this should also include a schedule for testing (weekly, monthly, and quarterly).

step2.title: Conduct & Record
step2.description:
Conduct required tests and record internally (a sample template has been provided). 

Monthly tests can coincide with fire drills, as required by Colorado Department of Public Safety.

step3.title: Submit & Save
step3.description:
Once per quarter, collect all fire alarm inspection and testing records and submit here. 

Keep files on-site for at minimum two years (these may be requested by external inspectors during annual visits).

name: Elevator Inspection - Internal NO
description: Ensuring the safety and functionality of an elevator in a school environment is crucial for the safety of students, staff, and visitors. A monthly internal inspection helps in early detection of potential issues, maintaining compliance with safety regulations, and prolonging the life of the elevator. This internal inspection should be carried out by trained school maintenance staff or a designated person with basic knowledge of elevator operations.

step1.title: Establish Policies
step1.description: Review Colorado Conveyance Regulations and requirements for elevator safety and inspections. Create inspection guidelines for school maintenance staff.

step2.title: Conduct Inspection
step2.description:
Conduct an inspection of your elevator each month. These inspections should include a visual inspection for apparent damage, a test of all operations within the elevator (buttons, phone, emergency stop), and an assessment of the ride for any unusual sounds or movements. 

Document all findings in an inspection report and/or maintenance log (template provided).

step3.title: Submit & Save
step3.description:
Once per quarter, submit your inspection tracker to verify ongoing inspection has occurred. 

Keep files on-site for at minimum two years.

name: Hazard Communication Plan (Middle/High School)
description: A Hazard Communication Program ensures that all staff and students are informed about the hazards associated with chemicals they may encounter at school. This program may be inspected, depending on the type and amount of hazardous materials used you instructional program (Art, Science, Wood Shop, etc) and in present in your facility. This program is essential for maintaining a safe educational environment by providing information on the proper handling, use, storage, and disposal of hazardous substances

step1.title: Inventory & Assess
step1.description:
Compile a comprehensive list of all chemicals used or stored in the school. Include cleaning supplies, science lab reagents, maintenance products, and any other hazardous materials.

Evaluate the risks associated with each chemical. Identify potential health hazards, environmental impacts, and the likelihood of exposure

step2.title: Develop Plan
step2.description:
Draft a detailed Hazardous Communication plan that includes procedures for labeling, safety data sheets (SDS), and employee/student training. The plan should outline responsibilities, emergency procedures, and methods for communicating hazards.

Ensure all chemical containers are properly labeled with the chemical name, hazard warnings, and manufacturer details. Maintain an accessible file of SDS for every chemical, providing detailed information on handling, exposure, and emergency measures.

step3.title: Train Staff
step3.description:
Develop a comprehensive training program for staff and students. Cover topics such as understanding labels, interpreting SDS, safe handling procedures, and emergency response actions.

The Department of Public Health and Environment will contact the school directly if they are required to complete. Make sure your staff is always aligned in their understanding and alignment to your program, as they will also conduct random in-person inspections. 

Submit a copy of your Hazard Communication Policy here and the inventory list of what is used in your school.

name: Hazardous Waste NO
description:
In alignment with hazardous material policies outlined in your school's Hazard Communication Plan, policies and procedures for the disposal of such materials. 

Ensure Hazardous Waste [science room chemicals, stains, acrylic, aerosol or floor paint, primers, shellacs, lacquers, varnishes, urethane waterproofing, certain pesticides, propane cylinders, fire extinguishers, etc .to include Universal Waste [batteries: including the ones in emergency (or frog) lights or fire alarm panel batteries, fluorescent light bulbs, electronic devices, lamps, etc. is properly disposed of.
Note: Latex paint is not considered a hazardous waste, but should be turned into a collection site

step1.title: Inventory Hazardous Materials
step1.description:
Compile a comprehensive list of all chemicals used or stored in the school. Include cleaning supplies, science lab reagents, maintenance products, and any other hazardous materials.

Review the Safety Data Sheets (SDS) for each hazardous material to find instructions for disposal.

step2.title: Create Disposal Plan
step2.description:
Create a guide, using the inventory and disposal instructions, which details policies and procedures for each type of hazardous waste. Update this guide whenever a new hazardous material is introduced. 

Ensure all staff handling or disposing of hazardous materials are trained on these policies and procedures. Early on, you may choose to keep a log detailing each disposal of hazardous waste to ensure alignment to your plan.

step3.title: Update & Monitor
step3.description:
Review your plan annually to ensure all hazardous materials are included. 

Train and refresh staff knowledge on hazardous waste procedures and review any disposal logs to ensure alignment. 

Submit your disposal plan and/or records here.

name: Fire Drill NO
description: The Colorado Division of Fire Prevention & Control and The Colorado School Safety Resource Center schools to conduct a fire drill in the first ten days of school, and then each month following. These drills ensure that all students and staff are aware of emergency procedures and prepared for evacuation if needed.

step1.title: Plan Drill
step1.description:
Schedule your drill for an appropriate time in the first two weeks of the month. 

Drills should be scheduled at unexpected times and under varying conditions each month (i.e. during different class periods, during lunch, or between class periods). 

Ensure that all students and staff have been prepared to execute evacuation procedures. Consider starting with planned or announced drills early in the year, progressing to unannounced drills as the year goes on.

step2.title: Execute Drill
step2.description:
Conduct your drill and record the duration. 

If your building has an alarm system, this must be used in the drill. Contact your alarm provider to put your system into "test mode" prior to starting the drill to avoid contacting the authorities. 

Inadvertent or false alarms cannot be used in place of a drill.

step3.title: Submit Drill Information
step3.description:
Record the results of the drill (sample template attached). These records should include, at minimum: 
1. The person conducting the drill.
2. Date and time of the drill.
3. Notification method used.
4. Employees on duty and participating.
5. Number of occupants evacuated.
6. Special conditions simulated.
7. Problems encountered.
8. Weather conditions when occupants were evacuated.
9. Time required to accomplish complete evacuation.

Maintain these records at the school for review during annual fire inspections and submit quarterly to confirm compliance.

name: Fire Alarm Inspection - External
description: In accordance with Colorado state code and in alignment with best practices established by the National Fire Protection Agency (NFPA) standards, schools are required to inspect and test the function of their fire alarm systems regularly. In addition to self-inspections conducted by school personnel throughout the year (see "Fire Alarm Inspection - Internal"), inspections are also required annually by Certified Fire Inspectors. These inspections verify the findings of self-inspections and ensure the school is safe for all students and staff.

step1.title: Prepare for Inspection
step1.description:
Contact your local fire department/fire marshal to schedule your annual inspection (in some areas, the local fire agency may do this for you). 

Ensure all records of internal self-inspections and assessments are up to date and all documentation is available. Self-inspect your alarm system to verify functionality prior to visit.

step2.title: Host Inspection
step2.description:
Ensure a school staff member is available to guide and host the Certified Fire Inspector during your scheduled inspection; this person should be familiar with the alarm function and facility as it relates to fire safety. 

The inspector should update your "School Maintenance Inspection Form" in the process of inspection. Keep this for your records.

step3.title: Review Results
step3.description:
Review the results of your inspection and address deficiencies, if any. 

Scan your School Maintenance Inspection Form as evidence of completion and submit here.

name: Fire Sprinkler Inspection - Annual
description: In accordance with Colorado state code and in alignment with best practices established by the National Fire Protection Agency (NFPA) standards, schools are required to inspect and test the function of their fire sprinkler systems annually.

step1.title: Prepare for Inspection
step1.description:
Contact your local fire department/fire marshal to schedule your annual inspection (in some areas, the local fire agency may do this for you). 

Ensure all records of internal self-inspections and assessments are up to date and all documentation is available.

step2.title: Host Inspection
step2.description:
Ensure a school staff member is available to guide and host the Certified Fire Inspector during your scheduled inspection; this person should be familiar with fire sprinkler system.

The inspector should update your "School Maintenance Inspection Form" in the process of inspection. Keep this for your records.

step3.title: Review Results- Upload most current inspection report
step3.description:
Review the results of your inspection and address deficiencies, if any. 

Scan your School Maintenance Inspection Form as evidence of completion and submit here.


**If you have not had your inspection yet this year, please upload last years (most current), leave a note when you anticipate this years inspection, and submit.

name: Fire Sprinkler Inspection - 5-year
description: In accordance with Colorado state code and in alignment with best practices established by the National Fire Protection Agency (NFPA) standards, schools are required to ensure the functionality of their fire sprinkler system. This includes annual inspection and testing (see "Fire Sprinkler Inspection - Annual"), and a specialty test conducted every five years.

step1.title: Prepare for Inspection
step1.description:
Contact your local fire department/fire marshal to schedule your annual inspection (in some areas, the local fire agency may do this for you). 

Ensure all records of internal self-inspections and assessments are up to date and all documentation is available.

step2.title: Host Inspection
step2.description:
Ensure a school staff member is available to guide and host the Certified Fire Inspector during your scheduled inspection; this person should be familiar with fire sprinkler system.

The inspector should update your "School Maintenance Inspection Form" in the process of inspection. Keep this for your records.

step3.title: Review Results
step3.description:
Review the results of your inspection and address deficiencies, if any. 

Scan your School Maintenance Inspection Form as evidence of completion and submit here.

name: Kitchen Hood Inspection
description: In accordance with Colorado state code and in alignment with best practices established by the National Fire Protection Agency (NFPA) standards, schools are required to ensure the functionality and cleanliness of their kitchen ventilation systems, as evidenced by an annual inspection by a Certified Fire Inspector.

step1.title: Prepare for Inspection
step1.description:
Contact your local fire department/fire marshal to schedule your annual inspection (in some areas, the local fire agency may do this for you). 

Verify the condition of any kitchen hoods and ventilation systems. Ensure their function and cleanliness is in alignment with state code and NFPA standards (both available in resources). 

If your school does not have kitchen facilities (only warmers), skip to Step 3.

step2.title: Host Inspection
step2.description:
Ensure a school staff member is available to guide and host the Certified Fire Inspector during your scheduled inspection; this person should be familiar with the kitchen ventilation systems. 

The inspector should update your "School Maintenance Inspection Form" in the process of inspection. Keep this for your records.

step3.title: Review Results
step3.description:
Review the results of your inspection and address deficiencies, if any. 

Scan your School Maintenance Inspection Form as evidence of completion and submit here. 

If your school does not have kitchen facilities, select "There is nothing to submit for this report" and submit.

name: Fire Extinguisher Inspections - Annual
description: In accordance with Colorado state code and in alignment with best practices established by the National Fire Protection Agency (NFPA) standards, schools are required to ensure the functionality of all fire extinguishers through annual, five-year, and 12-year inspections.

step1.title: Prepare for Inspection
step1.description:
Contact your local fire department/fire marshal to schedule your annual inspection (in some areas, the local fire agency may do this for you). 

Do an internal inspection of all fire extinguishers; ensure extinguishers are present in all necessary locations, are up to date, and show no signs of physical damage (NFPA standards available in resources).

step2.title: Host Inspection
step2.description:
Ensure a school staff member is available to guide and host the Certified Fire Inspector during your scheduled inspection; this person should be familiar with the location and function of all fire extinguishers within the building. 

The inspector should update your "School Maintenance Inspection Form" in the process of inspection. Keep this for your records.

step3.title: Review Results- Upload most current report
step3.description:
Review the results of your inspection and address deficiencies, if any. 

Scan your School Maintenance Inspection Form as evidence of completion and submit here.

**If you have not had your inspection yet this year, please upload last years (most current), leave a note when you anticipate this years inspection, and submit.

name: Fire Extinguisher Inspections - 5-Year
description: In accordance with Colorado state code and in alignment with best practices established by the National Fire Protection Agency (NFPA) standards, schools are required to ensure the functionality of all fire extinguishers through annual, five-year, and 12-year inspections.

step1.title: Prepare for Inspection
step1.description:
Contact your local fire department/fire marshal to schedule your annual inspection (in some areas, the local fire agency may do this for you). 

Do an internal inspection of all fire extinguishers; ensure extinguishers are present in all necessary locations, are up to date, and show no signs of physical damage (NFPA standards available in resources).

step2.title: Host Inspection
step2.description:
Ensure a school staff member is available to guide and host the Certified Fire Inspector during your scheduled inspection; this person should be familiar with the location and function of all fire extinguishers within the building. 

The inspector should update your "School Maintenance Inspection Form" in the process of inspection. Keep this for your records.

step3.title: Review Results
step3.description:
Review the results of your inspection and address deficiencies, if any. 

Scan your School Maintenance Inspection Form as evidence of completion and submit here.

name: Fire Extinguisher Inspections - 12-Year
description: In accordance with Colorado state code and in alignment with best practices established by the National Fire Protection Agency (NFPA) standards, schools are required to ensure the functionality of all fire extinguishers through annual, five-year, and 12-year inspections.

step1.title: Prepare for Inspection
step1.description:
Contact your local fire department/fire marshal to schedule your annual inspection (in some areas, the local fire agency may do this for you). 

Do an internal inspection of all fire extinguishers; ensure extinguishers are present in all necessary locations, are up to date, and show no signs of physical damage (NFPA standards available in resources).

step2.title: Host Inspection
step2.description:
Ensure a school staff member is available to guide and host the Certified Fire Inspector during your scheduled inspection; this person should be familiar with the location and function of all fire extinguishers within the building. 

The inspector should update your "School Maintenance Inspection Form" in the process of inspection. Keep this for your records.

step3.title: Review Results
step3.description:
Review the results of your inspection and address deficiencies, if any. 

Scan your School Maintenance Inspection Form as evidence of completion and submit here.

name: Health Department Food Safety Inspections
description: To ensure a safe and sanitary environment for food preparation and service, schools in Colorado must adhere to the Department of Public Health and Environment, Division of Environmental Health and Sustainability, Rules and Regulations Governing Schools in the State of Colorado (6 CCR 1010-6). Regular food safety inspections are crucial for compliance and the health of students and staff.

step1.title: Prepare for Inspection
step1.description:
Review all requirements for health and safety as outlined in the state code (6 CCR 1010-6), and ensure your kitchen and cafeteria meets these requirements. 

Contact your local health department to schedule a food safety inspection; if possible schedule outside of times which may disrupt food service (however, note food preparation and serving may be required in inspection). 

Your local health department may also do random inspections, as opposed to scheduling.

step2.title: Conduct Inspection
step2.description:
Provide the inspector with full access to all food preparation and storage areas. The inspector will evaluate cleanliness, food handling practices, equipment sanitation, and employee hygiene.

The inspector will check for compliance with temperature control, cross-contamination prevention, and proper labeling and storage of food items according to the regulations.

step3.title: Review Results- Upload most current inspections report
step3.description:
Review the detailed inspection report provided by the health inspector. The report will highlight any areas of non-compliance and recommend corrective actions.

Implement any necessary changes or improvements to address deficiencies noted in the report.

Submit a copy of the report and any corrective actions (or follow-up inspections) here.

**If you have not had your inspection yet this year, please upload last years (most current), leave a note when you anticipate this years inspection, and submit.

**If this does not apply to you, please choose no submission and submit.

name: Emergency Drill Guidance NO
description: To ensure the safety of students and staff, each school must have specific plans developed in consultation with appropriate fire (and ideally law enforcement) officials, on how to best respond to emergency incidents. These plans should include information on fire safety, evacuation, and lockdown procedures.

step1.title: Review Guidance
step1.description:
Review the resources provided from the Colorado Division of Fire Prevention and Control and the Colorado School Safety Resource Center. 

Compare these standards against current building practices and policies.

step2.title: Draft Plan
step2.description:
Develop or edit policies and procedures for your current school context.

These should include a fire safety plan, which outlines the process for reporting and communicating fire threats, as well as the location and operation of on-site fire suppression equipment, the evacuation plan, and lockdown/active shooter plan. 

Note, plans for lockdowns and active shooter situations must consider fire codes, and should address the unlikely, but possible scenario of a fire alarm occurring during a lockdown.

step3.title: Train & Drill
step3.description:
Review these plans with all staff (and students as applicable). 

Fire evacuation drills are required monthly (see Fire Drill). While active shooter drills are not required, training and practice in alignment with the guidelines provided is recommended. 

Maintain records on-site and note completion here.

name: Fire Alarm Response (Lockdown/Lockout) NO
description: To ensure the safety of students and staff, each school must have specific plans developed in consultation with appropriate fire (and ideally law enforcement) officials, on how to best respond to emergency incidents. In addition to plans for both fire response/evacuation and lockdowns/lockouts, schools must prepare for the unlikely, but possible scenario of a fire alarm occurring during a lockdown, and prepare students and staff.

step1.title: Review Guidance & Plans
step1.description:
Review the resources provided from the Colorado Division of Fire Prevention and Control and the Colorado School Safety Resource Center. Compare these standards against current building practices and policies. 

Review current plans and practices for fire evacuations and lockdown/lockout policies in isolation.

step2.title: Draft Plan
step2.description:
Develop or edit policies and procedures for how administrators, teachers, staff, and students should react in the event that a fire alarm is activated during a lockdown (or if a threat is identified). 

Ensure plans are aligned to the guidance provided.

step3.title: Train & Drill
step3.description:
Review these plans with all staff (and students as applicable). 

If possible, simulate these situations in an active drill to ensure understanding from all students and staff. 

Maintain records on-site and note completion here.

name: Emergency Equipment (Eyewash/Shower/Hoods) NO
description: In alignment with state code (6 CCR 1010-6), schools with classrooms that areas where corrosives or irritating materials are used (labs, wood shop, etc.), must maintain important safety equipment, including eye wash stations, shower stations, and fume hoods.  This equipment is essential to ensuring the safety of students and staff in the event of an emergency. Annual testing and inspection of this equipment is required to maintain this level of safety.

step1.title: Review Requirements
step1.description:
Review the requirements for eye wash stations, shower stations, and fume hoods, as outlined in 6 CCR 1010-6. 

Guidelines for each piece of safety equipment are listed here, but please review the full regulation for other requirements (in Resources). 
- Eye Wash: An easily accessible (no more than 55ft or 10s from chemical storage/use) and hands-free fountain which provides a continuous flow of water capable of flushing both eyes simultaneously (note, the use of portable eye wash bottles as substitutes is not permitted).
- Shower Station: An easily accessible (no more than 55ft or 10s from chemical storage/use) safety shower, capable of providing continuous flowing water.
- Fume Hood: Sufficient fume hood capacity ventilation (a minimum face velocity of 100 fpm) for any activity producing hazardous toxic or noxious gases, mists, vapors, or dusts. Hoods must exhaust directly to the outside and shall be located a minimum of 10 feet from any building air-intakes or building openings.

step2.title: Inspect Equipment
step2.description:
Verify that all equipment meets standards outlined in Step 1. Test each piece of equipment in alignment with regulations and record results (sample inspection checklists provided). 

Note any non-functional equipment of areas of remediation. 

This can be done internally, or through a third-party contractor.

step3.title: Review Results
step3.description:
Review the results of the inspection and testing. Address any immediate and long-term areas of concern. If necessary, this may mean limiting the use of specific classrooms, or the hazardous materials within them until addressed. 

Submit inspection results here.

name: Playground Inspections
description: Ensuring the safety and compliance of a school playground is crucial for the well-being of students. In Colorado, playground inspections should follow state guidelines to guarantee all equipment and surfaces meet safety standards. This process must be conducted by a Certified Playground Safety Inspector. These inspections are required immediately (prior to student use) after the installation of any new playground equipment and then annually thereafter.

step1.title: Schedule Inspection
step1.description:
Identify and reach out to a Certified Playground Inspector (CPSI) through the National Recreation and Park Association (NRPA) or local directories.

Schedule an appointment for the inspection, providing details about the playground's location, size, and types of equipment.

step2.title: Conduct Inspection
step2.description:
Ensure all areas of the playground are accessible and free of obstructions.

Gather any maintenance records, previous inspection reports, and playground equipment manuals for the inspector's review.

Accompany the CPSI during the inspection to address any immediate concerns and areas of remediation.

step3.title: Review Results- Upload most current report
step3.description:
Review the inspection report provided by the CPSI, noting any required repairs or modifications. Implement necessary changes and schedule follow-up inspections as needed to ensure continuous compliance and safety.

Stay prepared for future inspections by conducting regular internal checks of playground equipment safety and function. 

Submit your inspection report here.

**If you have not had your inspection yet this year, please upload last years (most current), leave a note when you anticipate this years inspection, and submit.

**If you do not have a playground, choose no submission and submit.

name: GMAX Inspections NO
description: GMAX a measurement of how much force is absorbed by an artificial field, and testing measures the shock absorption of synthetic turf to ensure it is safe for student use. Higher GMAX measurements indicate a harder or less shock-absorbent field, which can lead to a greater risk of injury. Schools in Colorado with artificial fields must conduct GMAX inspections annually to ensure the ongoing safety of students.

step1.title: Schedule Inspection
step1.description:
Search for certified GMAX testing professionals through recognized organizations like the Synthetic Turf Council or local service providers.

Contact the chosen tester to schedule an inspection, providing specifics about the field location, turf type, and installation date.

step2.title: Conduct Inspection
step2.description:
Gather any installation records, maintenance logs, and previous GMAX test results to provide to the tester.

Be present during the GMAX test to observe the process and address any immediate questions.

step3.title: Review Results
step3.description:
Review the GMAX test report, noting the readings and any recommendations for maintaining or improving turf safety.

If the GMAX readings exceed safe limits, arrange for necessary maintenance or repairs, and schedule a follow-up Gmax test to ensure compliance.

Submit your GMAX inspection/test report here.

name: Backflow Prevention & Cross Connection NO
description: In order to maintain safe drinking water and comply with Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment regulations, schools must complete an annual inspection of their backflow prevention assembly. This assembly prevents contaminated water from reversing into the clean water supply, ensuring the health and safety of students and staff. Backflow assemblies must be tested by licensed backflow inspectors and results must be reported to your water system by the timeframe they specify.

step1.title: Schedule Inspection
step1.description:
Contact a certified backflow assembly tester. Ensure they are approved by the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment (CDPHE).

Arrange a convenient time for the inspection, ideally during non-peak hours to minimize disruption.

step2.title: Conduct Inspection
step2.description:
Allow the certified tester access to the backflow prevention assembly. The tester will examine the device for any signs of wear, leaks, or malfunctions.

The tester will perform a series of tests to ensure the assembly is functioning correctly. This includes checking for proper pressure and ensuring that no contaminated water can flow back into the clean supply.

step3.title: Review Results
step3.description:
Review the detailed inspection report provided by the tester, which will outline the condition of the backflow assembly and any necessary repairs or replacements.

Submit the completed inspection report to the local water authority and here for verification.

name: Grease Traps
description: To maintain proper kitchen operations and comply with local regulations, schools must complete regular inspections of their grease traps (if required by their jurisdiction). These requirements are maintained by the Department of Public Health and Environment Hazardous Materials and Waste Management Division and state code (6 CCR 1007-2). Inspections help prevent blockages and maintain sanitary conditions by ensuring the grease traps are effectively separating fats, oils, and grease (FOG) from wastewater.

step1.title: Schedule Inspection
step1.description:
Contact a licensed and experienced grease trap service provider. Ensure they are knowledgeable about Colorado's specific regulations and requirements.

Arrange a convenient time for the inspection, preferably outside of meal preparation hours to minimize disruption to kitchen operations.

step2.title: Conduct Inspection
step2.description:
Allow the service provider access to the grease trap. The inspector will remove the lid and measure the levels of grease, solids, and liquids inside.

The inspector will check for any signs of damage, corrosion, or blockages. They will also ensure that the baffles and other components are in good working condition.

step3.title: Review Results
step3.description:
Review the detailed inspection report provided by the service provider, which will outline the condition of the grease trap and any necessary cleaning, repairs, or maintenance.

[color=rgb(0, 0, 0)][highlight=transparent]Upload most current load ticket report.[/highlight][/color]

**If this does not apply to you, please choose no submission and submit.

name: Final Assurance of Financial Accreditation
description: In accordance with state law (C.R.S. 22-30.5-112(7)), all charter schools are required to comply with all of the state financial and budget rules, regulations, and financial reporting requirements, in,  with which the chartering school district is required to comply.  The assurance form is completed by schools to attest to their compliance with these regulations.

step1.title: Review Assurances & Financial Practices
step1.description:
Review the assurance form (attached in Resources in the Draft of Assurances of Financial Accreditation benchmark) and compare to current school financial practices, verifying alignment. 

If the school is out of compliance with any assurance statement, implement changes to financial practices or obtain documentation for deviations.

step2.title: Complete Assurance Form
step2.description:
Download and complete the assurance form with your school information. 

If you answer "No" to any indicators, documentations is also required.

step3.title: Finalize & Submit
step3.description:
Once completed, submit your final assurances. D49 Finance requires a final AFA to ensure completion and compliance upon the official deadline in order to submit.

Your charter schools specialist will send all Final Assurances for Final Accreditation forms to CDE via schoolfinance@cde.state.co.us

name: Financial Transparency- Quarterly Website Check
description:
In alignment with the Financial Transparency Act (C.R.S. 22-44-301 et seq.) and the Charter Contract, all charter schools are required to post financial data and information in an free, accessible, and downloadable format. Schools must post and update financial documents regularly, to maintain financial transparency. For more information, you can visit the District or state websites: 
- Colorado K-12 Financial Transparency
- D49 Financial Transparency

step1.title: Collect & Review Financial Documents
step1.description:
If you are a new school, review and collect the list of required financial documentation. If you are an existing school, ensure all information and documentation is present and accessible on your website. 
- Charter School Adopted Budget - Including Uniform Budget Summary (current and prior two years) 
- Charter School Financial Audit (current and prior two years)
- Charter School Salary Schedules or Policies (current and prior two years) 
- List of Waivers Received by the Charter School
- Standardized Description and Rationale for Each Automatic Waiver
- Federal Form 990, 990-EZ, or 990-PF and any associated schedules (if you filed an extension for your 990(s), please enter a note into the benchmark and publish the extension on the website)
- Other Charter School-Specific Financial Information
- Link to Authorizing School District’s Financial Transparency Webpage
- Link to Public Financial Transparency Website View

step2.title: Review & Updated Website
step2.description:
Review and update all documentation as needed. Test all document links and downloads to ensure functionality.

Please note, all documents must be posted or updated within 60 days after completion or receipt of the applicable report, statement, or document.

Additionally, the Financial Transparency icon with the Colorado Flag must be found on the home page of school's website and link to all information included in this report (icon image available in Resources).

step3.title: Ready for Review
step3.description:
Once all information has been updated and added to the website, complete the report by checking "There is nothing to upload for this report" on the Completion page. 

Optional: Upload a screenshot of the website showing the visible links/files for all financial documents (please do not upload all documents here).

name: Quarterly Financial Statement (Q1)
description: In accordance with Colorado code and charter contracts, D49 schools are required to prepare (C.R.S. §22-45-102(1)(b)) and post (C.R.S. §22-44-301) quarterly financial reports to ensure fiscal responsibility, oversight, and transparency. These reports must be submitted in a timely manner: within 45 days of the end of each quarter.

step1.title: Collect Financial Data
step1.description:
Collect financial data from internal accounting systems for the previous quarter (Apr-Jun). 

Ensure included are budget vs. actuals (current and YTD), as well as information which demonstrates financial health and projected revenue/expenses (accounting for October counts).

step2.title: Enter Financial Data
step2.description:
Review the financial data and prepare for submission. This data should include at minimum: 
- Account codes following the CDE Chart of Accounts
- Current budget
- Month-to-date actuals
- Year-to-date actuals

All data should be collected and recorded in the attached template (Excel required for submission).

step3.title: Submit Data
step3.description: Review the data for accuracy and download as an Excel file (.xls) - the platform will not accept other file types for this submission.

name: Charter School Board Governance Compliance
description: In alignment with both Colorado Open Meeting laws, and the charter contract, schools are required to ensure that board members are aware the policies and responsibilities of board participation. This includes understanding conflicts of interest and the requirements of board participation through training and verification.

step1.title: Coordinate Board Meeting
step1.description:
Identify or schedule a board meeting near the end/beginning of the new school/fiscal year to review (and complete as able) governance requirements. 

These annual requirements include: 
1. Board resolution identifying the posting location for all meeting notices
2. Board Member Certification signed by each board member annually
3. Evidence of board training

These requirements can all be completed as a part of a board meeting (recommended), or reviewed and completed asynchronously as needed.

step2.title: Complete Requirements
step2.description:
Draft a resolution identifying the posting location for all meeting notices. At the meeting, the board must vote on and pass this resolution. Once established, ensure that appropriate/required information is posted and updated regularly (meeting schedule, roster, agendas, minutes). 

During this same meeting (or electronically), each board member should also review and sign the certification form (in Resources).

Ensure all board members complete training for the year. This can be self-led or completed utilizing one of the following resources: 
- Online Training with CLCS board training modules
- CDE board training modules
- CCSP grant board training

step3.title: Collect Documentation
step3.description:
Collect and review all documentation for submission. This should include: 
- Board resolution (signed by board chair or with minutes including the passing of the resolution)
- Certification forms signed by all board members
- Evidence of completed board training for all members

name: Capital Construction Expenditure
description: In the interest of promoting a safe and healthy learning environment for all Colorado students, each year the State Education Fund and a percentage of the marijuana excise tax provide an appropriation for Charter School and Institute Charter School Capital Construction (C.R.S. 22-54-124). Schools are able to use the funding for school construction, renovation, or facility purchase or leasing, but must report on these expenditures to the state to remain in compliance.

step1.title: Identify & Expend Funds
step1.description:
Funding for this program is determined by the previous year's October count, and school-level funding information can be found here. 

After determining your school's allocation, identify acceptable fund usage through needs assessment and collaboration between school leaders and the board of directors. In general, allowable expenses include: construction, demolition, remodeling, maintaining, financing, purchasing, or leasing of land, buildings, or facilities. 

Review the program guidance (in Resources) for full details on fund use and allowable/unallowable expenses.

step2.title: Complete Report
step2.description:
Once grant funds have been expended, complete the CDE Capital Construction Expenditure Eligibility Report on the CDE website. 

In order to complete this form, ensure you have information regarding the general expenditure categories (i.e. construction, demolition, remodeling) and total amount expended.

step3.title: Collect Documentation
step3.description:
Once completed, save a copy of the submitted report (Google Form) and take a screenshot of the confirmation of submission to CDE (this may also come as an email verification). 

Submit both the completed report and evidence of submission to CDE. 

If you need additional help with verification report completion, contact Brandon LaChance (720-910-3686 / csccreporting@cde.state.co.us).

name: October - Board Meeting Agenda
description: In alignment with Colorado's Open Meeting Law, board meeting agendas must be provided ahead of public board meetings. Public agendas not only provide transparancy, but also ensure meetings are organized and timely.

step1.title: Determine Content
step1.description: Through consultation with board committees and the Board Chair, determine appropriate content for the upcoming board meeting.

step2.title: Create Agenda
step2.description:
Organize content for the board meeting into an agenda. 

Topics may include (but are not limited to): Call to Order, Approval of Previous Minutes, Financial Reports, Academic Reports, New Business, Public Comments, Executive Session (if necessary), Adjournment (a template is provided as a reference).

step3.title: Submit Agenda
step3.description:
Review the agenda with necessary board members. 

Once finalized, submit the agenda to Reportwell.

name: September - Board Meeting Minutes
description: In the interest of transparency and in alignment with the Colorado Open Meetings Act, charter boards are required to keep minutes at all monthly board meetings. These minutes then must be reviewed for accuracy and approved by board members at subsequent meetings and provided as public record.

step1.title: Record Meeting Minutes
step1.description:
At your monthly board meeting, ensure an individual is identified to take the meeting minutes. These minutes should align to the previously provided agenda for that month's meeting. 

Minutes do not need to be a full transcript of the meeting, however they should include relevant content, questions, and comments. Any votes taken should also be recorded in the minutes (see sample minutes for example). 

After the meeting, this person should review and edit their notes for clarity and accuracy and send them to the Board Chair and Principal.

step2.title: Approve Minutes
step2.description:
Previous meeting minutes should be included with materials for the next board meeting. Before and during the meeting, board member must review and vote to approve the meeting minutes.

In general, the approval of meeting minutes takes place in the following month (i.e. June minutes are approved and submitted in July).

step3.title: Submit Minutes
step3.description:
Once approved, meeting minutes should be downloaded and uploaded to Reportwell. 

If previous meeting minutes have not been approved by the item due date, add a note to Reportwell indicating the date of the upcoming board meeting and when approved minutes will be uploaded.

name: Enrollment and Registration Materials
description: In accordance with state code (C.R.S. 22-30.5-104(3)), all schools must ensure fair and equitable enrollment processes, ensuring no discriminatory practices exist, "...on the basis of disability, race, creed, color, sex, sexual orientation, national origin, religion, ancestry, or need for special education services." Furthermore, enrollment in a charter school must be open to any student within the school district, so long as this enrollment does not require the school to alter their facility or change the function of rooms. Enrollment and registration materials are reviewed to ensure these standards are being met and upheld.

step1.title: Establish Enrollment Practices
step1.description:
Review enrollment and registration best practices and establish school policies and procedures for enrolling new students, and re-enrolling returning students. 

These policies should entail a clear description of the general process for enrolling all students and any additional practices for enrolling students with disabilities. You may also identify and create policies and procedures for special circumstances that may prioritize enrollment (i.e. sibling priority, staff member child priority), while establishing safeguards to ensure non-discrimination. 

In accordance with your charter contract, establish class/grade size capacities for the upcoming year and establish policies to manage enrollment once these limits are reached (lottery, wait list).

step2.title: Update Website
step2.description:
Update your school's' website with established enrollment policies created in the previous step. The website does not need to include all internal practices, but must include, at minimum: 
- Overview of the enrollment process (general and for students with disabilities)
- An anti-discrimination statement on the main page or enrollment page 
- Language stating that the school serves students with disabilities.
- Mission statement that includes language indicating the intention to serve all students, or a link to the anti-discrimination statement.
- Pre-admission forms that only ask for minimum required information (not disability status or status as another protected class). 

You may also choose to house your enrollment application or registration packet (next step) on the website, though this is not required. 

These items do not need to be submitted directly in Reportwell; instead the authorizer will a conduct school website check.

step3.title: Create & Submit Documents
step3.description:
Create or review/edit important enrollment and registration documents, including, but not limited to the enrollment application and registration packet. 

Once finalized, submit these forms for review. Additionally, verify in the comment during submission that the website has been updated and is ready for review.

name: November - Board Meeting Agenda
description: In alignment with Colorado's Open Meeting Law, board meeting agendas must be provided ahead of public board meetings. Public agendas not only provide transparancy, but also ensure meetings are organized and timely.

step1.title: Determine Content
step1.description: Through consultation with board committees and the Board Chair, determine appropriate content for the upcoming board meeting.

step2.title: Create Agenda
step2.description:
Organize content for the board meeting into an agenda. 

Topics may include (but are not limited to): Call to Order, Approval of Previous Minutes, Financial Reports, Academic Reports, New Business, Public Comments, Executive Session (if necessary), Adjournment (a template is provided as a reference).

step3.title: Submit Agenda
step3.description:
Review the agenda with necessary board members. 

Once finalized, submit the agenda to Reportwell.

name: October - Board Meeting Minutes
description: In the interest of transparency and in alignment with the Colorado Open Meetings Act, charter boards are required to keep minutes at all monthly board meetings. These minutes then must be reviewed for accuracy and approved by board members at subsequent meetings and provided as public record.

step1.title: Record Meeting Minutes
step1.description:
At your monthly board meeting, ensure an individual is identified to take the meeting minutes. These minutes should align to the previously provided agenda for that month's meeting. 

Minutes do not need to be a full transcript of the meeting, however they should include relevant content, questions, and comments. Any votes taken should also be recorded in the minutes (see sample minutes for example). 

After the meeting, this person should review and edit their notes for clarity and accuracy and send them to the Board Chair and Principal.

step2.title: Approve Minutes
step2.description:
Previous meeting minutes should be included with materials for the next board meeting. Before and during the meeting, board member must review and vote to approve the meeting minutes.

In general, the approval of meeting minutes takes place in the following month (i.e. June minutes are approved and submitted in July).

step3.title: Submit Minutes
step3.description:
Once approved, meeting minutes should be downloaded and uploaded to Reportwell. 

If previous meeting minutes have not been approved by the item due date, add a note to Reportwell indicating the date of the upcoming board meeting and when approved minutes will be uploaded.

name: Fire Inspection Review
description: Safety & Health Compliance Specialist will schedule and meet the fire inspector and building manager to walk through the inspection and aid the building manager on closing any deficiencies

step1.title: Conduct Inspection
step1.description: Schedule and conduct your fire inspection (see Fire Inspection report).

step2.title: Review Findings
step2.description:
Following the inspection, create a plan and address any deficiencies. 

Provide a summary which includes: deficiency, proposed/completed actions, and date/summary of completion (sample template provided).

step3.title: Follow-Up
step3.description: Select "There is nothing to submit for this report" and include the date of your inspection/anticipated date. D49's Health & Safety Specialist will receive and review findings directly from the fire chief and follow-up on any deficiencies.

name: December - Board Meeting Agenda
description: In alignment with Colorado's Open Meeting Law, board meeting agendas must be provided ahead of public board meetings. Public agendas not only provide transparancy, but also ensure meetings are organized and timely.

step1.title: Determine Content
step1.description: Through consultation with board committees and the Board Chair, determine appropriate content for the upcoming board meeting.

step2.title: Create Agenda
step2.description:
Organize content for the board meeting into an agenda. 

Topics may include (but are not limited to): Call to Order, Approval of Previous Minutes, Financial Reports, Academic Reports, New Business, Public Comments, Executive Session (if necessary), Adjournment (a template is provided as a reference).

step3.title: Submit Agenda
step3.description:
Review the agenda with necessary board members. 

Once finalized, submit the agenda to Reportwell.

description: In the interest of transparency and in alignment with the Colorado Open Meetings Act, charter boards are required to keep minutes at all monthly board meetings. These minutes then must be reviewed for accuracy and approved by board members at subsequent meetings and provided as public record.

step1.title: Record Meeting Minutes

Minutes do not need to be a full transcript of the meeting, however they should include relevant content, questions, and comments. Any votes taken should also be recorded in the minutes (see sample minutes for example).
