step3.title: Submit Minutes
step3.description:
Once approved, meeting minutes should be downloaded and uploaded to Reportwell. 

If previous meeting minutes have not been approved by the item due date, add a note to Reportwell indicating the date of the upcoming board meeting and when approved minutes will be uploaded.

name: Fire Alarm Inspection - Internal NO
description: In accordance with Colorado state code and in alignment with best practices established by the National Fire Protection Agency (NFPA) standards, schools are required to inspect and test the function of their fire alarm systems regularly. In addition to inspections required annually by Certified Fire Inspectors (see "Fire Alarm Inspection - External"), schools must self-inspect and test systems on a weekly, monthly, and quarterly basis. These practices ensure the safety and well-being of all students and staff attending the school daily.

step1.title: Establish Policies
step1.description:
Review Colorado state codes and requirement, as well as the NFPA Standards and Codes for fire alarm safety (access available online) as needed to ensure alignment in the school's fire alarm systems. You may also choose to review previous inspection reports from past years. 

Using these resources, establish policies and procedures for the regular inspection and testing of your alarm system; this should also include a schedule for testing (weekly, monthly, and quarterly).

step2.title: Conduct & Record
step2.description:
Conduct required tests and record internally (a sample template has been provided). 

Monthly tests can coincide with fire drills, as required by Colorado Department of Public Safety.

step3.title: Submit & Save
step3.description:
Once per quarter, collect all fire alarm inspection and testing records and submit here. 

Keep files on-site for at minimum two years (these may be requested by external inspectors during annual visits).

name: Elevator Inspection - Internal NO
description: Ensuring the safety and functionality of an elevator in a school environment is crucial for the safety of students, staff, and visitors. A monthly internal inspection helps in early detection of potential issues, maintaining compliance with safety regulations, and prolonging the life of the elevator. This internal inspection should be carried out by trained school maintenance staff or a designated person with basic knowledge of elevator operations.

step1.title: Establish Policies
step1.description:
Review Colorado Conveyance Regulations and requirements for elevator safety and inspections. Create inspection guidelines for school maintenance staff. 

If you school does not have an elevator, skip to Step 3.

step2.title: Conduct Inspection
step2.description:
Conduct an inspection of your elevator each month. These inspections should include a visual inspection for apparent damage, a test of all operations within the elevator (buttons, phone, emergency stop), and an assessment of the ride for any unusual sounds or movements. 

Document all findings in an inspection report and/or maintenance log (template provided).

step3.title: Submit & Save
step3.description:
Once per quarter, submit your inspection tracker to verify ongoing inspection has occurred. 

Keep files on-site for at minimum two years. 

If you school does not have an elevator, select "There is nothing to submit for this report" and submit.

name: Fire Drill NO
description: The Colorado Division of Fire Prevention & Control and The Colorado School Safety Resource Center schools to conduct a fire drill in the first ten days of school, and then each month following. These drills ensure that all students and staff are aware of emergency procedures and prepared for evacuation if needed.

step1.title: Plan Drill
step1.description:
Schedule your drill for an appropriate time in the first two weeks of the month. 

Drills should be scheduled at unexpected times and under varying conditions each month (i.e. during different class periods, during lunch, or between class periods). 

Ensure that all students and staff have been prepared to execute evacuation procedures. Consider starting with planned or announced drills early in the year, progressing to unannounced drills as the year goes on.

step2.title: Execute Drill
step2.description:
Conduct your drill and record the duration. 

If your building has an alarm system, this must be used in the drill. Contact your alarm provider to put your system into "test mode" prior to starting the drill to avoid contacting the authorities. 

Inadvertent or false alarms cannot be used in place of a drill.

step3.title: Submit Drill Information
step3.description:
Record the results of the drill (sample template attached). These records should include, at minimum: 
1. The person conducting the drill.
2. Date and time of the drill.
3. Notification method used.
4. Employees on duty and participating.
5. Number of occupants evacuated.
6. Special conditions simulated.
7. Problems encountered.
8. Weather conditions when occupants were evacuated.
9. Time required to accomplish complete evacuation.

Maintain these records at the school for review during annual fire inspections and submit quarterly to confirm compliance.

name: Charter Board Revised Budget
description: Each year, schools must create an operating budget, reflecting standards of financial stability as established by D49. This budget must be presented to the school's Board of Directors and approved before submission. The mid-year, revised budget is required to demonstrate that the school has taken into account any necessary revisions in response to any changes of circumstance (adjusted PPR rates, student count, etc.).

step1.title: Review Budget & Update Budget
step1.description:
Review your current year budget. Analyze projected and actual revenue and expenses (budget vs. actuals), and any underlying causes for disparities.

Update your projected revenues and expenses for the remainder of the year, noting changes to enrollment, staffing, or expected receipt/non-receipt of funds.

step2.title: Draft Budget
step2.description:
Review your updated budget and ending cash balance. In the event of excess profit or loss, review and identify potential areas for adjustment to expenses.

Draft an updated budget which includes proposed additions or cuts in response to your analysis. You may consider drafting several options for adjustment to propose to the governing board. 

*For guidance on budget creation, please see supporting documents.

step3.title: Finalize & Submit
step3.description:
Present the drafted budget to the governing board during your November or December board meeting. The board should provide feedback, suggested possible changes, and vote to approve the budget.

If the additional amendments to the budget and the board cannot vote to approve before the Jan 1st due date, submit the draft budget and a note indicating when the finalized budget will be approved. 

Once finalized, submit the budget as an Excel document here.

name: Elevator Inspection - External NO
description: Ensuring the safety and functionality of an elevator in a school environment is crucial for the safety of students, staff, and visitors. A monthly internal inspection helps in early detection of potential issues, maintaining compliance with safety regulations, and prolonging the life of the elevator. In addition to monthly internal inspections, all schools with operating elevators must conduct an inspection with an external conveyance inspector twice annually to verify functionality and safety.

step1.title: Schedule Inspection
step1.description:
Contact a external organization to complete your elevator inspection (between July and December). Possible entities include (but are not limited to): Otis, Morning Star or ThyssenKrupp.

If you school does not have an elevator, skip to Step 3.

step2.title: Host Inspection
step2.description: Ensure a school staff member is available to guide and host the Conveyance Inspector during your scheduled inspection; this person should be familiar with the location and function of any elevators within the building (and should ideally be the person conducting monthly internal inspections).

step3.title: Review Results
step3.description:
Review the results of your inspection and address deficiencies, if any. Submit any inspection records/reports in Reportwell. 

If you school does not have an elevator, select "There is nothing to submit for this report" and submit.

name: Radon Sampling - Child Care NO
description: Due to statistically high radon levels state-wide, and in the interest of student and faculty safety, the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment (CDPHE) requires schools and child care centers to test for this dangerous gas. Child care facilities are required to have their facilities tested for radon within six months of occupancy. Radon testing is only required to be done one time but it is recommended to retest every five years.

step1.title: Schedule Inspection
step1.description:
Colorado law requires special qualifications to perform radon testing. Schools and child care providers must either obtain the qualifications for testing or hire a qualified radon professional when testing their building. More information about these requirements and exemptions can be found on the Colorado Department of Regulatory Agencies website.

If there is not someone at the school/child care center qualified, find a professional to conduct radon testing. Some local public health agencies may also have a radon professional that is able to test your facility for free or at a low cost.

step2.title: Conduct Inspection
step2.description:
Schedule a time with your qualified staff or hired professional to test your school or child care facility for radon during the colder months of the year (between October and April), but still before the six-month requirement. 

It is not recommended to conduct testing when the school or child care facility is closed for a break or over the weekend. Normal activity, when children and staff are in the building, during the testing period will provide the most accurate representation of radon levels.

step3.title: Review Results
step3.description:
Review the results of your inspection and create a plan to address any necessary remediation. 

Provide a copy of your results here and keep on file at the school or child care facility (these must be provided to anyone who requests to see them).

Minutes do not need to be a full transcript of the meeting, however they should include relevant content, questions, and comments. Any votes taken should also be recorded in the minutes (see sample minutes for example). 

After the meeting, this person should review and edit their notes for clarity and accuracy and send them to the Board Chair and Principal.

If previous meeting minutes have not been approved by the item due date, add a note to Reportwell indicating the date of the upcoming board meeting and when approved minutes will be uploaded.

name: Title IX Compliance (Website Check)
description:
Title IX has been a part of federal law since 1972 to address sexual harassment and discrimination in school districts, school settings, school based activities, and athletics. In May 2020, significant changes were made to the Title IX regulations, which K-12 school districts are required to adhere to when receiving federal funding. These changes include a requirement of Title IX recipients to designate individuals in specific roles and ensure completion of associated training. Additionally, schools must make Title IX reporting information readily available to ensure that the educational community understands how to submit a potential complaint. 

Additional questions regarding Title IX requirements can be directed to Dr. Nancy Lemmond, Title IX Coordinator, Civil Rights Investigator (nancy.lemmond@d49.org)

step1.title: Identify Title IX Coordinator
step1.description:
Identify an individual at your school to serve as the Title IX Coordinator; this person will be responsible for coordinating grant efforts and ensuring compliance. The assigned coordinator must complete necessary training. 

Post the name of the Title IX Coordinator and contact information on the school's website. This contact information must include the title, office address, e-mail address, and telephone number of the coordinator. 

Note: The school must designate and train all Title IX personnel, however these do not need to be made public on the school's website (see Title IX Compliance report guide for full instructions).

step2.title: Establish Reporting Guidance
step2.description:
Establish practices for the submission and processing of Title IX complaints and reports. 

Note: Any person may report sex discrimination, including sexual harassment (whether or not the person reporting is the person alleged to be the victim of conduct that could constitute sex discrimination or sexual harassment)using the contact information listed for the Title IX Coordinator. Such a report may be made at any time, including during non-business hours, by using the telephone number or e-mail address, or by mail to the office address listed for the Title IX Coordinator. 

Once procedures have been established, post Title IX reporting/complaint information and directions to the school's website (alongside the Title IX Coordinator's contact information).

step3.title: Post Training Materials
step3.description:
In addition to the Title IX Coordinator, ensure all other roles (Investigator, Decision Maker, Informal Resolution Facilitators, Appeals) have been assigned and training has been completed. Please note, the regulations require that a different individual take on each role to maintain the fidelity of the process. For full instructions on training, see the Title IX Compliance report guide. 

Post your Title IX training materials for all roles on the school's website.  

Once all required documentation has been made public on the website, complete this report without documentation. The authorizer will review the website to verify compliance.

name: Title IX Compliance
description:
Title IX has been a part of federal law since 1972 to address sexual harassment and discrimination in school districts, school settings, school based activities, and athletics. In May 2020, significant changes were made to the Title IX regulations, which K-12 school districts are required to adhere to when receiving federal funding. Please review the attached resources to familiarize yourself with all requirements. 

Additional questions regarding Title IX requirements can be directed to Dr. Nancy Lemmond, Title IX Coordinator (nancy.lemmond@d49.org/ (719) 494-8913).

step1.title: Identify Title IX Personnel
step1.description:
Institutions are responsible for having individuals train and serve in the following roles: 
- Coordinator
- Investigator
- Decision Maker
- Informal Resolution Facilitators
- Appeals

The regulations require that a different individual take on each role to maintain the fidelity of the process.

step2.title: Conduct Training for Assigned Staff
step2.description:
Training of Title IX personnel must include training on the definition of sexual harassment in the Final Rule, the scope of the school’s education program or activity, how to conduct an investigation and grievance process including hearings, appeals, and informal resolution processes, as applicable, and how to serve impartially, including by avoiding prejudgment of the facts at issue, conflicts of interest, and bias.

Additionally, decision-makers must receive training on any technology to be used at a live hearing and both  decision-makers and investigators must receive training on issues of relevance.

step3.title: Draft & Finalize Process
step3.description:
In coordination with Title IX staff, draft a decision making framework and process to address Title IX compliance and respond to potential complaints. 

Review and finalize your draft against the updated guidelines and expectations. 

Submit this plan as well as Title IX staff (who holds each role) and evidence of training.

name: Annual School Calendar w/ Contact Days
description: The year-long school calendar is an essential communication tool, creating alignment between the school and authorizer, and ensuring compliance with the minimum student contact day requirement for Colorado.

step1.title: Draft Basic Calendar
step1.description:
Utilizing the previous years' template (or a sample provided here) and identify start and end dates for each part of the year. 

Block out any federal holidays and other previously established school days off, as well as seasonal breaks.  Add additional important in and out-of-school days to the calendar (this may be detailed to preference but should at minimum include days out of school). Do a preliminary count of the total student contact days.

Per state code (C.R.S. 22-32-109), Colorado schools are required to have 160 total student contact days in their calendar; use your previous count to ensure that any additional days off do not bring your total below this count.

step2.title: Establish Schedule
step2.description:
Create (or edit previous year's) daily schedule, noting the start and end time and total instructional hours per day. Instructional hours should not be counted for time students are at school at the beginning and end of day (outside of instruction) or lunch; recess and passing periods may be counted, unless prohibited by board policies (full guidance provided in resources). 

Calculate the total number of instructional hours created by your draft calendar (hours per day x total days). 

In additional to the 160 day requirement, Colorado schools must also ensure they meet the minimum instructional hour requirement for the school year (see resources for chart). Depending on grade level, this amounts to about 6.0-6.5 hours per day for a 160-day calendar. 

If the total instructional hours to not meet the required threshold, adjust the schedule or calendar. This may include adding additional days, adjusting early-release/half-days, or lengthening the school day.

step3.title: Finalize Calendar
step3.description:
Review and verify calendar dates with key stakeholders internally. Ensure your calendar notes the total number of student contact days and instructional hours (by grade if applicable). 

Once finalized, present to the governing board to approve. 

Submit your approved calendar as a PDF document.

name: Fire Alarm Inspection - Internal NO
description: In accordance with Colorado state code and in alignment with best practices established by the National Fire Protection Agency (NFPA) standards, schools are required to inspect and test the function of their fire alarm systems regularly. In addition to inspections required annually by Certified Fire Inspectors (see "Fire Alarm Inspection - External"), schools must self-inspect and test systems on a weekly, monthly, and quarterly basis. These practices ensure the safety and well-being of all students and staff attending the school daily.

step1.title: Establish Policies
step1.description:
Review Colorado state codes and requirement, as well as the NFPA Standards and Codes for fire alarm safety (access available online) as needed to ensure alignment in the school's fire alarm systems. You may also choose to review previous inspection reports from past years. 

Using these resources, establish policies and procedures for the regular inspection and testing of your alarm system; this should also include a schedule for testing (weekly, monthly, and quarterly).

step2.title: Conduct & Record
step2.description:
Conduct required tests and record internally (a sample template has been provided). 

Monthly tests can coincide with fire drills, as required by Colorado Department of Public Safety.

step3.title: Submit & Save
step3.description:
Once per quarter, collect all fire alarm inspection and testing records and submit here. 

Keep files on-site for at minimum two years (these may be requested by external inspectors during annual visits).

name: Elevator Inspection - Internal NO
description: Ensuring the safety and functionality of an elevator in a school environment is crucial for the safety of students, staff, and visitors. A monthly internal inspection helps in early detection of potential issues, maintaining compliance with safety regulations, and prolonging the life of the elevator. This internal inspection should be carried out by trained school maintenance staff or a designated person with basic knowledge of elevator operations.

step1.title: Establish Policies
step1.description:
Review Colorado Conveyance Regulations and requirements for elevator safety and inspections. Create inspection guidelines for school maintenance staff. 

If you school does not have an elevator, skip to Step 3.

step2.title: Conduct Inspection
step2.description:
Conduct an inspection of your elevator each month. These inspections should include a visual inspection for apparent damage, a test of all operations within the elevator (buttons, phone, emergency stop), and an assessment of the ride for any unusual sounds or movements. 

Document all findings in an inspection report and/or maintenance log (template provided).

step3.title: Submit & Save
step3.description:
Once per quarter, submit your inspection tracker to verify ongoing inspection has occurred. 

Keep files on-site for at minimum two years. 

If you school does not have an elevator, select "There is nothing to submit for this report" and submit.

name: Radon Sampling - School NO
description: Due to statistically high radon levels state-wide, and in the interest of student and faculty safety, the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment (CDPHE) requires schools and child care centers to test for this dangerous gas. Schools are required to have their buildings tested for radon within 19 months of occupancy. Radon testing is only required to be done one time but it is recommended to retest every five years.

step1.title: Schedule Inspection
step1.description:
Colorado law requires special qualifications to perform radon testing. Schools and child care providers must either obtain the qualifications for testing or hire a qualified radon professional when testing their building. More information about these requirements and exemptions can be found on the Colorado Department of Regulatory Agencies website.

If there is not someone at the school/child care center qualified, find a professional to conduct radon testing. Some local public health agencies may also have a radon professional that is able to test your facility for free or at a low cost.

step2.title: Conduct Inspection
step2.description:
Schedule a time with your qualified staff or hired professional to test your school or child care facility for radon during the colder months of the year (between October and April).

It is not recommended to conduct testing when the school or child care facility is closed for a break or over the weekend. Normal activity, when children and staff are in the building, during the testing period will provide the most accurate representation of radon levels.

step3.title: Review Results
step3.description:
Review the results of your inspection and create a plan to address any necessary remediation. 

Provide a copy of your results here and keep on file at the school or child care facility (these must be provided to anyone who requests to see them).

name: Proposed Budget
description: Each year, schools must create an operating budget, reflecting standards of financial stability as established by D49. This budget must be presented to the school's Board of Directors and approved before submission to D49.

step1.title: Review Budget
step1.description:
Review your previous' year's budget and identify your projected ending cash balance for the current fiscal year. 

OR (if this is your first year)

Select a budgeting template and your projected cash balance for the first day of the upcoming fiscal year (07/01).

step2.title: Draft Budget
step2.description:
Draft your budget for the upcoming year by projecting revenues (student enrollment, grant, other) and allocating expenses within that projected amount. 

*For guidance on budget creation, please see supporting documents.

step3.title: Review & Submit
step3.description:
Present the drafted budget to stakeholders and apply feedback as needed. Approval by the governing board is not required at this time, but an internal review is advised if possible. 

Submit the proposed budget in an Excel document.

name: Financial Transparency- Quarterly Website Check
description:
In alignment with the Financial Transparency Act (C.R.S. 22-44-301 et seq.) and the Charter Contract, all charter schools are required to post financial data and information in an free, accessible, and downloadable format. Schools must post and update financial documents regularly, to maintain financial transparency. For more information, you can visit the District or state websites: 
- Colorado K-12 Financial Transparency
- D49 Financial Transparency

step1.title: Collect & Review Financial Documents
step1.description:
If you are a new school, review and collect the list of required financial documentation. If you are an existing school, ensure all information and documentation is present and accessible on your website. 
- Charter School Adopted Budget - Including Uniform Budget Summary (current and prior two years) 
- Charter School Financial Audit (current and prior two years)
- Charter School Salary Schedules or Policies (current and prior two years) 
- List of Waivers Received by the Charter School
- Standardized Description and Rationale for Each Automatic Waiver
- Federal Form 990, 990-EZ, or 990-PF and any associated schedules (if you filed an extension for your 990(s), please enter a note into the benchmark and publish the extension on the website)
- Other Charter School-Specific Financial Information
- Link to Authorizing School District’s Financial Transparency Webpage
- Link to Public Financial Transparency Website View

step2.title: Review & Updated Website
step2.description:
Review and update all documentation as needed. Test all document links and downloads to ensure functionality.

Please note, all documents must be posted or updated within 60 days after completion or receipt of the applicable report, statement, or document.

Additionally, the Financial Transparency icon with the Colorado Flag must be found on the home page of school's website and link to all information included in this report (icon image available in Resources).

step3.title: Ready for Review
step3.description:
Once all information has been updated and added to the website, complete the report by checking "There is nothing to upload for this report" on the Completion page. 

Optional: Upload a screenshot of the website showing the visible links/files for all financial documents (please do not upload all documents here).

name: Assessment Calendar
description: All Colorado schools are required to administer a number of standardized assessments throughout the school year. Schools are required to create a detailed calendar outlining the timing and administration of these assessments to ensure testing compliance, while also allowing D49 to schedule submissions related to local assessments.

step1.title: Collect Assessment Information
step1.description:
Review Colorado Department of Education requirements and administration windows for statewide assessments (in resources). 

With your school team, identify any additional local assessments you plan to administer throughout the year, in addition to state tests. 

For each assessment, identify the number of students that need to take the assessment and the number of staff needed to administer the assessment.

step2.title: Create Calendar
step2.description:
Utilizing the assessment information collected create a calendar of assessments that account for student need and staff capacity. 

A specific template is not require, but a sample calendar has been provided as a reference.

step3.title: Review & Submit
step3.description:
Review the assessment schedule with academic leaders and stakeholders to ensure feasibility. 

Once finalized, download the completed schedule and submit as a PDF.

name: Annual Selection of Normed Assessment
description:
Reference:
Charter Contract Section 7 Educational Program
Submission:

step1.title: Identify Normed Assessments
step1.description: Identify any normative assessments (e.g. STAR 360, NWEA MAPS, etc.) that are used by the school in assessing student growth and attainment (not including required state assessments - see Assessment Calendar).

step2.title: Provide Rationale
step2.description:
Provide a description of each normed assessment selected by the school. 

Explain how each assessment will be used to measure student performance and growth. Indicate how this assessment will meet the academic goals specified within the charter contract.

step3.title: Review & Submit
step3.description: Finalize your list of normed assessments and submit as a PDF document.

name: Board Approved Budget
description: Each year, schools must create an fiscally-sound operating budget to be reviewed by the district to facilitate planning and support. This budget must be presented to the school's Board of Directors and approved as evidenced by meeting minutes and posted publically on the school's website.

step1.title: Update Budget
step1.description: Updated your drafted budget with any required edits as a result of feedback (from the Board of Directors or other stakeholders) and/or to address refined projections (student enrollment, staffing, etc.)

step2.title: Review & Approve Budget
step2.description:
Present the updated budget to the Board of Directors during a spring meeting (Apr-May). 

The board must approve and vote on the finalized budget. If the board cannot come to a consensus and vote, a follow-up meeting and vote must be held.

step3.title: Finalize & Submit
step3.description:
Finalize any approved changes to the board-approved budget and submit. 

If, for some reason, the board is unable to vote on the budget ahead of the June 1st due date, submit the draft budget and include a note with the expected completion date. 

Once approved/adopted, post your finalized budget or budget summary on your school's website.

name: Actual Enrollment Report
description: Per the school's Charter Contract with the District, enrollment data must be shared quarterly. This information allows the District to remain aware and responsive to school needs and budgets as they relate to total enrollment numbers. This is the final enrollment report of the fiscal year.

step1.title: Collect Enrollment Data
step1.description: Utilizing the school's internal student information system (SIS), collect enrollment numbers (total and by grade).

step2.title: Complete Enrollment Form
step2.description:
Use the data collected to complete the attached template. 

This template should be downloaded to your computer and updated each quarter to save time and ensure all quarter-to-quarter enrollment numbers are saved in the same document.

step3.title: Review & Submit
step3.description: Verify all information in the attached document is correct and submit.

name: Fire Drills and Emergency Guidance
description: All public schools are required to ensure safe conditions for students, and appropriately prepare for possible emergencies. Preparation includes adequate emergency drills and the maintenance of a school emergency operations plan which is reviewed and updated annually, aiding schools in effectively preparing for threats and hazards that may affect their institution.

step1.title: Conduct & Record Monthly Drills
step1.description:
Fire Code requires schools to conduct a fire drill within ten days of the first day of school and once a month thereafter. 

Each month, plan, execute, and record a fire drill (see the attached resources for drill procedures and a template for record-keeping). 

Also note, the state code does not allow for the substitution of any other type of drill (e .g. lockdown, lockout, or shelter) for a fire drill.

step2.title: Review & Update Emergency Plans
step2.description:
With school leaders, review guidelines and best practices for school safety and emergency preparedness (resources attached). Discuss and apply these guidelines in the context of your unique school environment.

Obtain your school's existing Emergency Preparedness Plan (if applicable). 

Utilizing your notes from discussions of best practices, review and edit your existing plan, or draft a new plan if one does not exist (template/examples attached).

Ensure your schools' Emergency Contacts are included and updated in this plan.

step3.title: Review & Submit
step3.description:
Review and edit your Emergency Plan, leveraging stakeholder feedback (staff, families). Additionally, you can consult with local first responders to refine and improve plans each year.

Collect all fire drill records for the year (please combine into one file if possible). 

Submit your fire drill records, Emergency Preparedness Plan, and Emergency Contact information (if not included in plan) before submitting. 

**Please note, submissions received after 4:00 pm on June 30, will be marked as "Did Not Comply".

name: June - Board Meeting Agenda
description: In alignment with Colorado's Open Meeting Law, board meeting agendas must be provided ahead of public board meetings. Public agendas not only provide transparancy, but also ensure meetings are organized and timely.

step1.title: Determine Content
step1.description: Through consultation with board committees and the Board Chair, determine appropriate content for the upcoming board meeting.

step2.title: Create Agenda
step2.description:
Organize content for the board meeting into an agenda. 

Topics may include (but are not limited to): Call to Order, Approval of Previous Minutes, Financial Reports, Academic Reports, New Business, Public Comments, Executive Session (if necessary), Adjournment (a template is provided as a reference).

step3.title: Submit Agenda
step3.description:
Review the agenda with necessary board members. 

Once finalized, submit the agenda to Reportwell.

name: Fire Alarm Inspection - Internal NO
description: In accordance with Colorado state code and in alignment with best practices established by the National Fire Protection Agency (NFPA) standards, schools are required to inspect and test the function of their fire alarm systems regularly. In addition to inspections required annually by Certified Fire Inspectors (see "Fire Alarm Inspection - External"), schools must self-inspect and test systems on a weekly, monthly, and quarterly basis. These practices ensure the safety and well-being of all students and staff attending the school daily.

step1.title: Establish Policies
step1.description:
Review Colorado state codes and requirement, as well as the NFPA Standards and Codes for fire alarm safety (access available online) as needed to ensure alignment in the school's fire alarm systems. You may also choose to review previous inspection reports from past years. 

Using these resources, establish policies and procedures for the regular inspection and testing of your alarm system; this should also include a schedule for testing (weekly, monthly, and quarterly).

step2.title: Conduct & Record
step2.description:
Conduct required tests and record internally (a sample template has been provided). 

Monthly tests can coincide with fire drills, as required by Colorado Department of Public Safety.

step3.title: Submit & Save
step3.description:
Once per quarter, collect all fire alarm inspection and testing records and submit here. 

Keep files on-site for at minimum two years (these may be requested by external inspectors during annual visits).

name: May - Board Meeting Minutes
description: In the interest of transparency and in alignment with the Colorado Open Meetings Act, charter boards are required to keep minutes at all monthly board meetings. These minutes then must be reviewed for accuracy and approved by board members at subsequent meetings and provided as public record.

step1.title: Record Meeting Minutes
step1.description:
At your monthly board meeting, ensure an individual is identified to take the meeting minutes. These minutes should align to the previously provided agenda for that month's meeting. 

Minutes do not need to be a full transcript of the meeting, however they should include relevant content, questions, and comments. Any votes taken should also be recorded in the minutes (see sample minutes for example). 

After the meeting, this person should review and edit their notes for clarity and accuracy and send them to the Board Chair and Principal.

step2.title: Approve Minutes
step2.description:
Previous meeting minutes should be included with materials for the next board meeting. Before and during the meeting, board member must review and vote to approve the meeting minutes.

In general, the approval of meeting minutes takes place in the following month (i.e. June minutes are approved and submitted in July).

step3.title: Submit Minutes
step3.description:
Once approved, meeting minutes should be downloaded and uploaded to Reportwell. 

If previous meeting minutes have not been approved by the item due date, add a note to Reportwell indicating the date of the upcoming board meeting and when approved minutes will be uploaded.

name: Carbon Monoxide in Schools
description: Carbon monoxide (CO) is an odorless gas, sometimes emitted through fuel sources and dangerous when inhaled at long intervals. The Colorado Division of Fire Prevention & Control and the Colorado School Safety Resource Center has outlined specific circumstances in which schools must install CO detectors to ensure the safety of students and staff.

step1.title: Review Facility Specifications
step1.description:
Determine if CO detectors are needed in any areas of the school. Currently conditions that warrant the use of CO detector are: 
1. Classrooms that contain a fuel-burning appliance or fuel-burning fireplace (gas-fired heating units, Bunsen burners, etc.)
2. Classrooms that are serviced by a fuel-fired forced-air system.

step2.title: Install or Check Detectors
step2.description:
If carbon monoxide detectors are not present in any required spaces, install detectors as needed. 

For previously installed detectors, check the functionality of each unit.

step3.title: Record
step3.description:
Record the location and function of all carbon monoxide detectors within the school. Update as needed. 

Check regularly to ensure the continued function of each unit and maintain records on-site.

name: Purchased Services Selection Form
description: D49 offers a variety of services, at actual cost, to charter schools outside of what is covered under the general administrative overhead fee. Every year, the list of service offerings is updated and sent out to schools by February 15. The school then has the opportunity to elect which services they would like for the next school year.

step1.title: Review Services
step1.description:
Review the list of potential services and associated fees: 
- Special Education
- Central Administrative Overhead
- District Support
- PowerSchool
- Learning Management System
- School Nurse Induction (as applicable)
- CLDE Credentialing Program

step2.title: Select Services
step2.description:
Identify possible services and project associated fees into proposed budget. 

Review proposed services (if any) and make selections.

step3.title: Complete Form
step3.description:
Complete the Purchased Services Selection form (resources) with your selected services.

Submit as needed (due date set to the end of the fiscal year).

name: Quarterly Enrollment Report
description: Per the school's Charter Contract with the District, enrollment data must be shared quarterly. This information allows the District to remain aware and responsive to school needs and budgets as they relate to total enrollment numbers.

step1.title: Collect Enrollment Data
step1.description: Utilizing the school's internal student information system (SIS), collect enrollment numbers (total and by grade).

step2.title: Complete Enrollment Form
step2.description:
Use the data collected to complete the attached template. 

This template should be downloaded to your computer and updated each quarter to save time and ensure all quarter-to-quarter enrollment numbers are saved in the same document.

step3.title: Review & Submit
step3.description: Verify all information in the attached document is correct and submit.

name: Elevator Inspection - Internal NO
description: Ensuring the safety and functionality of an elevator in a school environment is crucial for the safety of students, staff, and visitors. A monthly internal inspection helps in early detection of potential issues, maintaining compliance with safety regulations, and prolonging the life of the elevator. This internal inspection should be carried out by trained school maintenance staff or a designated person with basic knowledge of elevator operations.

step1.title: Establish Policies
step1.description:
Review Colorado Conveyance Regulations and requirements for elevator safety and inspections. Create inspection guidelines for school maintenance staff. 

If you school does not have an elevator, skip to Step 3.

step2.title: Conduct Inspection
step2.description:
Conduct an inspection of your elevator each month. These inspections should include a visual inspection for apparent damage, a test of all operations within the elevator (buttons, phone, emergency stop), and an assessment of the ride for any unusual sounds or movements. 

Document all findings in an inspection report and/or maintenance log (template provided).

step3.title: Submit & Save
step3.description:
Once per quarter, submit your inspection tracker to verify ongoing inspection has occurred. 

Keep files on-site for at minimum two years. 

If you school does not have an elevator, select "There is nothing to submit for this report" and submit.

name: Elevator Inspection - External NO
description: Ensuring the safety and functionality of an elevator in a school environment is crucial for the safety of students, staff, and visitors. A monthly internal inspection helps in early detection of potential issues, maintaining compliance with safety regulations, and prolonging the life of the elevator. In addition to monthly internal inspections, all schools with operating elevators must conduct an inspection with an external conveyance inspector twice annually to verify functionality and safety.

step1.title: Schedule Inspection
step1.description:
Contact a external organization to complete your elevator inspection (between July and December). Possible entities include (but are not limited to): Otis, Morning Star or ThyssenKrupp.

If you school does not have an elevator, skip to Step 3.

step2.title: Host Inspection
step2.description: Ensure a school staff member is available to guide and host the Conveyance Inspector during your scheduled inspection; this person should be familiar with the location and function of any elevators within the building (and should ideally be the person conducting monthly internal inspections).

step3.title: Review Results
step3.description:
Review the results of your inspection and address deficiencies, if any. Provide any inspection records/reports here. 

If you school does not have an elevator, select "There is nothing to submit for this report" and submit.

name: October Count - Verify Teacher Attendance
description: The purpose of the Student October Snapshot is to determine funding for Local Education Agencies (LEAs) districts and schools by taking a count of students in attendance on the Pupil Enrollment Date (10/01/2024). In addition to being enrolled with the district, students must also meet the attendance requirements in order to be considered for funding.

step1.title: Review Attendance
step1.description:
Verify all attendance records are accurate through your SIS. 

Send a notification stressing the importance of October Count and submitting attendance every day.

step2.title: Run Audit
step2.description:
Run the teacher attendance submission audit to see what teachers are not consistently submitting attendance.

Full instructions found in Resources.

step3.title: Verify Completion
step3.description: Verify audit completion through Reportwell - select "There is nothing to submit for this report" to submit.

name: October Count - Independent Study Attendance
description: The purpose of the Student October Snapshot is to determine funding for Local Education Agencies (LEAs) districts and schools by taking a count of students in attendance on the Pupil Enrollment Date (10/01/2024). In addition to being enrolled with the district, students must also meet the attendance requirements in order to be considered for funding.

step1.title: Review Attendance
step1.description: If your school is offering any Independent Study Classes you will need to submit how attendance will be tracked for CDE review and approval.

step2.title: Run Audit
step2.description: There is no standard attendance format due to the uniqueness of each independent study class. Please submit your preferred attendance example to be submitted to CDE. Failure to submit this attendance request for Independent Study classes, may result in these classes not being eligible for funding calculations.

step3.title: Verify Completion
step3.description: If you aren't offering any Independent Study, please indicate that rather than submitting examples of attendance tracking methods.

description: The purpose of the Student October Snapshot is to determine funding for Local Education Agencies (LEAs) districts and schools by taking a count of students in attendance on the Pupil Enrollment Date (10/01/2024). In addition to being enrolled with the district, students must also meet the attendance requirements in order to be considered for funding.

step1.title: Review AUD Questions
step1.description: Review the AUD 110 and At Risk forms in resources and send the questions to the appropriate staff within your school for details on how your school manages those items.

step2.title: Combine Answers
step2.description: Compile all answers into the appropriate documents

step3.title: Submit
step3.description: Submitted the completed questionnaires through ReportWell to be combined with the operated D49 responses.

name: October Count - Identify Consecutive Absences
description: The purpose of the Student October Snapshot is to determine funding for Local Education Agencies (LEAs) districts and schools by taking a count of students in attendance on the Pupil Enrollment Date (10/01/2024). Accurate attendance tracking early in the year helps to identify students no longer enrolled at the school and ensures accurate October counts.

step1.title: Review Attendance
step1.description:
Verify all attendance records are accurate through your SIS. 

Send a notification stressing the importance of October Count and submitting attendance every day.

step2.title: Run Report
step2.description:
Run the consecutive absence report to see students who have not consistently been attending. 

For students identified with consecutive absences, connect with the teachers to confirm if the student has ever attended (due to inconsistencies in some teachers submitting attendance). 

Follow-up with families of no-show students to determine if they have been absent or are transferring. If transferring, assign to moving class and begin follow up on adequate documentation of transfer to withdraw.

step3.title: Verify Completion
step3.description: Verify report completion through Reportwell - select "There is nothing to submit for this report" to submit.

name: October Count - New Student Packets
description: The purpose of the Student October Snapshot is to determine funding for Local Education Agencies (LEAs) districts and schools by taking a count of students in attendance on the Pupil Enrollment Date (10/01/2024). New student enrollments for the current year must include sufficent documentation to ensure accurate October counts.

step1.title: Process New Enrollments
step1.description: Process new student enrollments according to internal policies and procedures.

step2.title: Compile Documents
step2.description: Collect all documents outlined in the guide provided in Resources for each new student enrollment.

step3.title: Upload Documents
step3.description:
Save all documents in one pdf document using the appropriate naming convention: SchoolCode_NewStudent_StudentSASID

Upload all new enrollment packets by the due date. You can continue to add additional enrollments to this report if new enrollments occur after initial submission (or add to the next report, if able).

step1.description: Process new student enrollments according to internal policies and procedures.

step2.title: Compile Documents

Upload all new enrollment packets by the due date. You can continue to add additional enrollments to this report if new enrollments occur after initial submission (or add to the next report, if able).

name: Kitchen Hood Inspection
description: In accordance with Colorado state code and in alignment with best practices established by the National Fire Protection Agency (NFPA) standards, schools are required to ensure the functionality and cleanliness of their kitchen ventilation systems, as evidenced by an annual inspection by a Certified Fire Inspector.

step1.title: Prepare for Inspection
step1.description:
Contact your local fire department/fire marshal to schedule your annual inspection (in some areas, the local fire agency may do this for you). 

Verify the condition of any kitchen hoods and ventilation systems. Ensure their function and cleanliness is in alignment with state code and NFPA standards (both available in resources). 

If your school does not have kitchen facilities (only have warmers), skip to Step 3.

step2.title: Host Inspection
step2.description:
Ensure a school staff member is available to guide and host the Certified Fire Inspector during your scheduled inspection; this person should be familiar with the kitchen ventilation systems. 

The inspector should update your "School Maintenance Inspection Form" in the process of inspection. Keep this for your records.

step3.title: Review Results
step3.description:
Review the results of your inspection and address deficiencies, if any. 

Scan your School Maintenance Inspection Form as evidence of completion and submit here. 

If your school does not have kitchen facilities, select "There is nothing to submit for this report" and submit.

name: Playground Inspections
description: Ensuring the safety and compliance of a school playground is crucial for the well-being of students. In Colorado, playground inspections should follow state guidelines to guarantee all equipment and surfaces meet safety standards. This process must be conducted by a Certified Playground Safety Inspector. These inspections are required immediately (prior to student use) after the installation of any new playground equipment and then annually thereafter.

step1.title: Schedule Inspection
step1.description:
Identify and reach out to a Certified Playground Inspector (CPSI) through the National Recreation and Park Association (NRPA) or local directories.

Schedule an appointment for the inspection, providing details about the playground's location, size, and types of equipment.

step2.title: Conduct Inspection
step2.description:
Ensure all areas of the playground are accessible and free of obstructions.

Gather any maintenance records, previous inspection reports, and playground equipment manuals for the inspector's review.

Accompany the CPSI during the inspection to address any immediate concerns and areas of remediation.

step3.title: Review Results
step3.description:
Review the inspection report provided by the CPSI, noting any required repairs or modifications. Implement necessary changes and schedule follow-up inspections as needed to ensure continuous compliance and safety.

Stay prepared for future inspections by conducting regular internal checks of playground equipment safety and function. 

Submit your inspection report here.

description: The purpose of the Student October Snapshot is to determine funding for Local Education Agencies (LEAs) districts and schools by taking a count of students in attendance on the Pupil Enrollment Date (10/01/2024). name: Assurance of Compliance
description: The Assurance of Compliance document is an acknowledgement and agreenment by the school to abide by all reporting and administrative requirements laid out in the Charter Contract. By signing this document, the school indicates it is aware of the statutes, rules and policies set forth in the assurances, as well as certain information from governing documents, including the applicable charter school application (new school, renewal, or transfer) and contract. The school further acknowledges and confirms that it is in compliance with such statutes, rules, policies, and other applicable documents.

step1.title: Review Documents
step1.description:
Read through each item on Assurance of Compliance document as well as related compliance requirements in the Charter Application or Contract. 

These documents should be review by relevant school leaders and board members.

step2.title: Sign Assurances
step2.description: Once reviewed, update the signature pages with school and signer information. Signatures are required from School Leader and School Board President.

step3.title: Review & Submit
step3.description: Review & Submit

name: October Count - Handbook (secondary and programs)
description: The purpose of the Student October Snapshot is to determine funding for Local Education Agencies (LEAs) districts and schools by taking a count of students in attendance on the Pupil Enrollment Date (10/01/2024). In this process, high schools, online schools, and unique schools/programs are required to submit their student handbook and course descriptions to ensure appropriate funding. This is optional but encouraged for all other schools.

step1.title: Review Handbook
step1.description:
Draft or review and update your student handbook for the year. 

Save the finalized handbook with the appropriate naming convention: SchoolCode_Handbook

step2.title: Create Course Descriptions
step2.description:
Collect or draft descriptions for all courses in which active students are enrolled/are receiving credit. 

Download finalized course descriptions (no naming convention). If this information is contained in your student handbook this does not need to be a separate document.

step3.title: Submit Documents
step3.description:
[b]This additional benchmark is for schools to upload what they have in order to give the Data and Performance team time to go over your submission and look for errors and suggest edits. If you do not utilize this benchmark, please know that the team may not have enough time to review your document before the final due date to CDE.[/b]

Upload your finalized handbook and course descriptions to Reportwell. 

If this is not required for your school and you choose not to complete, select "There is nothing to complete for this report" and submit (indicate in the comment that this is an optional requirement for your school).

name: TSDL - Final CDE Submission
description: The Teacher-Student Data Link file captures data that link students in 6th through 12th grade to courses and instructors (if available) for the school year. This collection helps provide transparency and accountability on student course participation and achievement, migrant student progress, and educator preparation program efficacy.

step1.title: Collect & Review Data
step1.description: Review the final TSDL file submission to CDE. Verify that the report is error free and ready for verification.

step2.title: Verification
step2.description: Verification sheet will be signed by authorizer.

step3.title: Submit Verification
step3.description: Signed verification will be submitted on behalf of charter school.

name: SASID Requests
description: The Record Integration Tracking System enables CDE to conduct detailed analysis of student performance over time by assigning unique student identifiers to each student in the State of Colorado, known as the SASID. The SASID is a 10-digit number and is often the same as the school’s student ID, but not always. It depends on the district. Be sure to check with your data services contact. The Record Integration Tracking System enables CDE to conduct detailed analysis of student performance over time by assigning unique student identifiers to each student in the State of Colorado, known as the SASID. The SASID is a 10-digit number used in CDE reporting.

step1.title: Identify students in need of SASID
step1.description: Gather all necessary student information.

step2.title: Enter into spreadsheet
step2.description: Use provided template. You must enter all information requested in order for your request to be processed.

step3.title: Submit
step3.description:
Upload report and submit. 

Please watch for communications regarding your errors report (if there are any). *Important* You may be asked to provide a birth certificate for students that cannot be easily identified or if RITS returns a duplicate. This is to prevent the use of duplicates as that clean up process later is the year is extensive. Birth certificates can be sent via Reportwell messaging.

 SASIDS will be returned to you via Reportwell messaging.

step1.title: Identify students in need of SASID

name: CogAT Rostering
description: We need a roster of students that are NOT coded for Gifted and Talented. This is to test said students for Gifted and Talented.

step1.title: Using Sample Template
step1.description:
By using the template we provided for you, please fill out with current students in the fields we have identified. 

In the Unique ID field, Please put the first letter of your school name in before the student's LASID. James Irwin Elementary School would be Jxxxxxx. Pioneer Technical would be Pxxxxxx.

step2.title: Return File
step2.description: Once file is filled out, please return to Reportwell so we can load into CogAT.

step3.title: Awaiting Confirmation
step3.description: We will look over the file and either submit it to CogAT rostering or we will return it to you so you can fix any error that we find and we will let you know what the error/errors is and where it is so it can be fixed and processed.

step3.title: Review & Submit

name: HR Snapshot- 1st Deadline- Staff Profile and Assignment
description:
[b]Please pull data as of 9/30/2024. This 1st deadline is to have time for the D49 team to check for errors and get those errors corrected. [/b]

[color=rgb(0, 0, 0)]The Human Resources collection contains all staff information as of the official staff count date (12/1/24). CDE uses this information for school staff demographics, average salaries by position and education level, highly qualified status for teachers and paraprofessionals, turnover rates and educator effectiveness ratings. [/color][color=rgb(0, 0, 255)][highlight=rgb(255, 255, 255)]The HR Snapshot is also used to populate the CDE Special Education December Count Snapshot to report special education staff serving students with disabilities.[/highlight][/color]

step1.title: Complete Templates
step1.description: [color=rgb(0, 0, 0)]Complete the Staff Profile and Staff Assignment templates (included in Resources) for all currently employed and purchased staff. Utilize the "File Layout & Definition" documents found in Resources for support in completion of these templates. [/color][color=rgb(0, 0, 255)][highlight=rgb(251, 249, 246)]Ensure that the Special Education Assignment Flag is Yes for all staff with a full time or partial Special Education Assignment. [/highlight][/color]

step2.title: Upload to Reportwell
step2.description: [color=rgb(0, 0, 0)]Upload your completed Staff Profile and Staff Assignment files to Reportwell. Error report will be sent via benchmark notes.[/color]

step3.title: Error Report
step3.description: Correct errors and resubmit.

name: HR Snapshot- 2nd Deadline- Staff Profile and Assignment
description:
[b]Please pull any employee data from last submission (1st deadline)-12/01/2024 timeframe. This 2nd deadline is to add to your first file if you had new hires after first submission, [i][u]please do not include already reported employees[/u].[/i] D49 team will need to have time to check for errors/get errors corrected. If you have no new hires as of your first submission AND your first submission is error-free please choose "no submission" and submit. [/b]

The Human Resources collection contains all staff information as of the official staff count date (12/1/24). CDE uses this information for school staff demographics, average salaries by position and education level, highly qualified status for teachers and paraprofessionals, turnover rates and educator effectiveness ratings. [color=rgb(0, 102, 204)]The HR Snapshot is also used to populate the CDE Special Education December Count Snapshot to report special education staff serving students with disabilities.[/color]

step1.title: Complete Templates
step1.description: [color=rgb(0, 0, 0)]If you had any new hires as of first submission, complete the Staff Profile and Staff Assignment templates (included in Resources) for all currently employed and purchased staff. Utilize the "File Layout & Definition" documents found in Resources for support in completion of these templates. [/color]If your school had errors from the, please locate the error report in the HR Snapshot- Deadline 1 notes.

step2.title: Error Report
step2.description: Correct errors.

step3.title: Upload to Reportwell
step3.description: [color=rgb(0, 0, 0)]Upload your completed Staff Profile and Staff Assignment (with new hires as of first submission) files to Reportwell. Any additional error report will be sent via benchmark notes [/color][b][color=rgb(0, 0, 0)]on this benchmark.[/color][/b]

name: EDID Request
description: The Educator Identification System (EDIS) assigns each educator in the state of Colorado a unique Identification Number (ID) that will follow the educator throughout their service in Colorado public education. The purpose of the educator ID is to be able to use a unique number that preserves the privacy of educator records while allowing statutorily required data analyses.

step1.title: Check for Existing EDID
step1.description: [color=rgb(0, 0, 0)]When bringing on new educators at your school, check for an existing EDID number through employee records. EDIDs are necessary for these state reports.[/color]

step2.title: Request EDID
step2.description: [color=rgb(0, 0, 0)]Fill out template and submit. **Please leave the first column blank (EDID) as this is where CDE will return the number**[/color]

step3.title: Receive EDID
step3.description: [color=rgb(0, 0, 0)]Check benchmark notes for EDID.[/color]

name: October Count- Verify Consecutive Absences
description: The purpose of the Student October Snapshot is to determine funding for Local Education Agencies (LEAs) districts and schools by taking a count of students in attendance on the Pupil Enrollment Date (10/01/2024). Accurate attendance tracking early in the year helps to identify students no longer enrolled at the school and ensures accurate October counts.

step1.title: Review Attendance
step1.description:
Verify all attendance records are accurate through your SIS. 

Send a notification stressing the importance of October Count and submitting attendance every day.

step2.title: Run Report
step2.description:
Run the consecutive absence report to see students who have not consistently been attending. 

For students identified with consecutive absences, connect with the teachers to confirm if the student has ever attended (due to inconsistencies in some teachers submitting attendance). 

Follow-up with families of no-show students to determine if they have been absent or are transferring. If transferring, assign to moving class and begin follow up on adequate documentation of transfer to withdraw.

step3.title: Verify Completion
step3.description: Verify report completion through Reportwell - select "There is nothing to submit for this report" to submit.

This template should be downloaded to your computer and updated each week to save time and ensure all week-to-week enrollment numbers are saved in the same document.

step3.title: Review and Submit
step3.description: Verify all information in the attached document is correct and submit.

name: October Count - Clear Moving Class
description: The purpose of the Student October Snapshot is to determine funding for Local Education Agencies (LEAs) districts and schools by taking a count of students in attendance on the Pupil Enrollment Date (10/01/2024). Per state board rule 1-CCR-301-1, LEAs are required to maintain adequate documentation of students transferring out of the school. This documentation assures all students are accounted for and prevents erroneous drop-outs.

step1.title: Update Records
step1.description:
Review state guidance for adequate procedures and documentation of transfers out of the school (see Resources).

Through the first months of school, update student enrollment records for new and transferred students.

step2.title: Process Transfers
step2.description:
For any students who have indicated a transfer to another school, request "Confirmation of Enrollment and Attendance" to new schools. 



LEAs are expected to respond promptly to one another regarding requests for transcripts or confirmation of enrollment and attendance. Per state board rule, LEAs must respond within two weeks of receiving the request with the exception of students in out-of-home placements whose records must be sent within five days of receiving the request. 



Any students confirmed to be transferring from the school should be placed in the "Moving Class" (full guidance and procedures in Resources).

step3.title: Clear Moving Class
step3.description:
Once transfers have been confirmed through documentation, clear out the moving class to ensure accurate numbers of enrollment. No student should be dropped from the moving class without proper attempts of locating the student. 

In addition, no student on an IEP or a 504 plan should be dropped from the moving class without communication with the Zone Special Education Coordinator (IEP) or Nancy Lemmond (504).

Some situations may prevent the ability to clear out a student from the Moving class, such as students within the truancy process. If you are unable to clear a student provide details of their truancy status to the D49 SIS Team(d49sis@d49.org). 

Verify your moving class has been cleared in Reportwell - select "There is nothing to submit for this report"

name: October Count - Bell Schedules
description: The purpose of the Student October Snapshot is to determine funding for Local Education Agencies (LEAs) districts and schools by taking a count of students in attendance on the Pupil Enrollment Date (10/01/2024). Daily schedules are used in the October count to verify part or full time status and funding codes.

step1.title: Create Schedules
step1.description:
Create schedules for all student and calendar variations.

This should include the regular bell schedule, as well as early-release or late start (i.e. weather delay) schedules, or schedules specific to certain students or student groups.

step2.title: Download Schedules
step2.description:
Once schedules have been finalized, save copies with the appropriate naming convention: Schoolcode_BellSchedule_Type. 

Example: 1275_Bell_Schedule_2HourDelay

step3.title: Submit
step3.description: Upload your schedule to Reportwell.

name: October Count - School Calendar
description: The purpose of the Student October Snapshot is to determine funding for Local Education Agencies (LEAs) districts and schools by taking a count of students in attendance on the Pupil Enrollment Date (10/01/2024). The year-long school calendar is an essential communication tool, and in the October count, ensures compliance with the minimum student contact day requirement for Colorado to establish funding.

step1.title: Create Calendar
step1.description:
Create or retrieve your school calendar. This can be the district calendar only if your school does not have any variation of days such as Red/Blue fridays, late start Thursdays, or a different start date

Verify any dates off - federal holidays, seasonal breaks, conference, PD - and the total number of contact days (minimum 160). 

For full calendar creation guidance see "Annual School Calendar w/ Contact Days"

step2.title: Download Schedules
step2.description: Once the calendar has been finalized, save with the appropriate naming convention: Schoolcode_SchoolCalendar

step3.title: Submit
step3.description: Upload your schedule to Reportwell.

name: October Count - IEP Summary Pages
description: The purpose of the Student October Snapshot is to determine funding for Local Education Agencies (LEAs) districts and schools by taking a count of students in attendance on the Pupil Enrollment Date (10/01/2024). In order to determine student funding status and enrollment, schools information on any students with varied schedule due to Individualized Learning Plans (IEPs).

step1.title: Identify Students
step1.description:
Identify any students that are on a reduced schedule only or participating in homebound education. 

Note these classifications should be supported and verified through documentation in the student's IEP.

step2.title: Update Records
step2.description:
Ensure accurate records by ensure their funding status is up to date in your Student Information System (SIS). 

Funding guidance and SIS instruction in Resources.

step3.title: Collect Documentation
step3.description:
Collect the summary from each student on reduced or homebound schedules. 

Save copies of these document using the naming convention: SchoolCode_IEPSummary_StudentSASID

Upload all student files to Reportwell.

name: October Count - Schedule Verification
description: The purpose of the Student October Snapshot is to determine funding for Local Education Agencies (LEAs) districts and schools by taking a count of students in attendance on the Pupil Enrollment Date (10/01/2024). In order to be accurately counted, all active students must have an assigned schedule for the entire school year.

step1.title: Review Data
step1.description: Verify all accuracy of all active students and schedules in your SIS.

step2.title: Verify Schedules
step2.description:
Confirm every active student has a full schedule for the entire school year. 

Verify all no-show and inactive students have the "moving class" on their schedule.

step3.title: Certify Completion
step3.description: Verify all records are updated through Reportwell - select "There is nothing to submit for this report" to submit.

name: October Count - Part-Time Funding
description: Double check your students schedule to verify if they qualify for part-time or full time funding (mainly secondary). If part-time, adjust their funding code as referenced in the linked document.

step1.title: Identify Students
step1.description: Identify any students that may qualify as part-time (this mainly applies to secondary students).

step2.title: Adjust Funding
step2.description: Adjust the funding codes for any students identified as part time in your SIS (see Resources for guidance and funding codes).

step3.title: Certify Completion
step3.description: Verify all records are updated through Reportwell - select "There is nothing to submit for this report" to submit.

name: October Count - Post Alternative Course Catalog to Website
description: The purpose of the Student October Snapshot is to determine funding for Local Education Agencies (LEAs) districts and schools by taking a count of students in attendance on the Pupil Enrollment Date (10/01/2024). In this process, high schools, online schools, and unique schools/programs are required to submit their student handbook and course descriptions to ensure appropriate funding. This is optional, but encouraged for all other schools.

step1.title: Upload to website
step1.description:
Ensure your alternative course catalog meets all CDE requirements. [color=rgb(17, 85, 204)][url=https://docs.google.com/document/d/1oPny3Kw3w9Myy0zAmWiUW_aoV8iiNII9vLNg7GOmDBo/edit?usp=sharing]We have linked that example here for your quick reference.[/url][/color]

[ml][ol][li indent=0 align=left]Have a separate course catalog listing only the alternative education classes [/li][/ol][/ml][ml][ul][ul data=1][li indent=1 align=left]These classes include: [/li][ul data=2][li indent=2 align=left]Work Study (internships, etc)[/li][li indent=2 align=left]Blended Learning[/li][li indent=2 align=left]Independent Study[/li][li indent=2 align=left]Supplemental Online[/li][/ul][li indent=1 align=left]This also includes expelled students at all grade levels for any/all online classes they will be taking[/li][ul data=2][li indent=2 align=left]Since expulsions are hard to plan for, please have a list of what classes any expelled student can choose from through your preferred online provider and ensure they are listed in your catalog [/li][li indent=2 align=left]The 1 direct instruction class will not need to be listed in this catalog [/li][/ul][/ul][/ul][/ml][ml][ol][li indent=0 align=left]The course catalog must include these items:[/li][/ol][/ml][ml][ul][ul data=1][li indent=1 align=left]School Name[/li][li indent=1 align=left]School Year [/li][li indent=1 align=left]Course name[/li][ul data=2][li indent=2 align=left]Note: for our elementary catalog I listed the course name that will show on the student schedule and the course name as it will show on the instructional provider's catalog for audit purposes[/li][/ul][li indent=1 align=left]Course description[/li][ul data=2][li indent=2 align=left]Note: I used the description from the equivalent SCED code for our catalog reviewed by CDE ([color=rgb(17, 85, 204)][url=https://nces.ed.gov/scedfinder/Home/Search?AspxAutoDetectCookieSupport=1]linked here for those not familiar with requesting courses[/url][/color]/sced codes) [/li][/ul][li indent=1 align=left]Credits[/li][li indent=1 align=left]Instructional Provider[/li][ul data=2][li indent=2 align=left]Example: SchoolsPLP or Edgenuity[/li][ul data=3][li indent=3 align=left]If using a program such as those above, also link their course catalog for CDE to review as shown in the example[/li][/ul][/ul][/ul][/ul][/ml]

step2.title: Upload to Website
step2.description: Upload your school's Alternative Instruction Course Catalog to your school's website

step3.title: Submit Documents
step3.description: Send D49 the link of where the catalog is posted (and a copy of the catalog if changes were made from the last deadline of 9/9)
